{{Infobox scientist | name = Albert S. Humphrey | image = Albert S Humphrey passport picture.jpg | birth_date = {{birth date|1927|6|2|df=yes}} | birth_place = | death_date = {{death date and age|2005|10|31|1926|6|2|df=yes}}<ref name="father">{{cite web|url=http://www.tamplc.com/Humphsprofile.htm|title=Albert Humphrey The "Father" of TAM|publisher=TAM UK|accessdate=2012-06-03}}</ref> | death_place = | nationality = | field = [[Management]] | work_institution = [[SRI International|Stanford Research Institute]] | alma_mater = [[University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign|University of Illinois]] (B.Sc.), [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology|M.I.T.]] (M.Sc.), [[Harvard University]] ([[Master of Business Administration|MBA]]) | doctoral_advisor = | influences = | influenced = | known_for = [[SWOT analysis]] }} '''Albert S. Humphrey''' (2 June 1926 – 31 October 2005) was an American business and [[Management consulting|management consultant]] who specialized in organizational management and [[Transformation of culture|cultural change]]. Initially earning degrees in chemical engineering in Illinois, he eventually moved to London.
Humphrey devoleped the [[SWOT analysis]] technique while working for the Stanford Research Institute, now known as [[SRI International]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.sri.com/sites/default/files/brochures/dec-05.pdf|title=SWOT Analysis for Management Consulting|first=Albert|last=Humphrey|work=SRI Alumni Newsletter|publisher=[[SRI International]]|date=December 2005}}</ref> . SWOT is a strategic planning method used to evaluate the Strengths, Weaknesses/Limitations, Opportunities, and Threats involved in a project or in a business venture. The origin of the term SWOT remains obscure.
== Education == Albert Humphrey was educated at the [[University of Illinois at Urbana–Champaign|University of Illinois]], where he graduated with a B.Sc. in [[Chemical engineering|Chemical Engineering]]. After this he gained a master's degree in chemical engineering at [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology|M.I.T.]] and an [[Master of Business Administration|MBA]] at [[Harvard University]].<ref name="father"/>
== Career == His work at the Stanford Research Institute (now [[SRI International]]) produced a team method for planning which created SOFT analysis and this was developed into [[SWOT analysis]].
One client was [[W.H. Smith]] (1970–1987), which aligned its annual budget to long-range planning. This programme was the first to use the concept of employee involvement in business planning and can be seen as sowing the seeds for the [[Investors in People]] scheme.
While continuing work at Stanford, Humphrey was involved with the team that came up with the Stakeholder Concept, which has often been referenced by business leaders, economists and politicians. This programme became known as TAM ([[Team Action Management]]).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.leader-values.com/content/detail.asp?ContentDetailID=872|title=Leadership Development - Results focused Leadership thinking and practice from around the Globe}}</ref>
During his working life Humphrey acted as consultant to over 100 companies globally. In 2005 he was listed in:<ref name="father"/>
* ''[[Marquis Who's Who#General publications|Who's Who in the World]]'' * [[Debrett's#Debrett's People of Today|Debrett's ''People of Today'']] * ''Who's Who in the City'' * ''The Directory of Directors''
In 2004 he was listed in the ''[[Marquis Who's Who#General publications|Who's Who in Science and Engineering]]'', 7th Edition (2003–2004).
== Family == Albert had four children with his first wife Virginia P. Humphrey. After several years they divorced, Albert moved to London and a decade passed before he met and married Myriam, with whom he had one daughter(Stephanie). They lived together until his death in 2005.
== Death == Albert S. Humphrey died on 31 October 2005 at the age of 79.

The '''American Plastics Council''' (APC) is a defunct [[trade association]] for the U.S. [[Plastics Industry|plastics industry]]. Through a variety of outreach efforts, APC works to promote the benefits of [[plastic]]s and the plastics industry. APC comprises 22 of the leading [[resin]] manufacturers, plus one affiliated trade association representing the [[Polyvinyl chloride|vinyl]] industry. APC's membership represents more than 80 percent of the U.S. [[monomer]] and [[polymer]] production and distribution capacity.
Members organizations are now represented by the [[American Chemistry Council]].

{{Infobox film | name = Arbitrage | image = Arbitrage 2012 Poster.jpg | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[Nicholas Jarecki]] | writer = Nicholas Jarecki | producer = {{ubl|Laura Bickford|Kevin Turen|Justin Nappi|[[Robert Salerno]]|Mohammed Alturki}} | starring = {{ubl|[[Richard Gere]]|[[Susan Sarandon]]|[[Tim Roth]]|[[Brit Marling]]|[[Laetitia Casta]]|[[Nate Parker]]}} | music = [[Cliff Martinez]] | cinematography = [[Yorick Le Saux]] | editing = [[Douglas Crise]] | studio = {{ubl|Green Room Films|Treehouse Pictures|Artina Films}} | distributor = [[Lionsgate]] | released = {{Film date|2012|01|21|Sundance Film Festival|2012|9|14|United States|2013|3|1|Ireland}} | runtime = 107 minutes | country = {{ubl|United States|Poland}} | language = English | budget = $12 million<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.the-numbers.com/movie/Arbitrage#tab=summary|title=Arbitrage (2012)|work=[[The Numbers (website)|The Numbers]]|accessdate=June 14, 2017}}</ref> | gross = $35.5 million<ref name="mojo">{{cite web |url= http://boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=arbitrage.htm|work= [[Box Office Mojo]]|title= Arbitrage (2012)|accessdate= 2012-05-10 }}</ref> }} '''''Arbitrage''''' is a 2012 American [[thriller film|thriller]] [[drama]] film directed by [[Nicholas Jarecki]] and starring [[Richard Gere]], [[Susan Sarandon]], [[Tim Roth]] and [[Brit Marling]].<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2012/09/02/movies/arbitrage-and-the-rich-and-troubled-bad-guy.html "And the Rich Shall Inherit the Woes" "New York Times", 31 August 2012]</ref> Filming began in April 2011 in [[New York City]]. It opened in U.S. theaters in September 2012.
==Plot== Sixty-year-old magnate Robert Miller ([[Richard Gere]]) manages a [[hedge fund]] with his daughter Brooke ([[Brit Marling]]) and is about to sell it for a handsome profit. However, unbeknownst to his daughter and most of his other employees, he has [[cooking the books|cooked his company's books]] in order to cover an investment loss and avoid being arrested for fraud. One night, while driving with his much younger mistress, Julie Cote ([[Laetitia Casta]]), he begins to doze off and crashes; Julie is killed. An injured Robert leaves the scene and decides to cover up his involvement to prevent the public, his wife Ellen ([[Susan Sarandon]]), and the prospective buyer James Mayfield ([[Graydon Carter]]) from discovering the truth.
Robert calls Jimmy Grant ([[Nate Parker]]), a twenty-three-year-old man from [[Harlem]] with a criminal record whom he helped get off the street in the past, and whose father had been Robert's driver for many years. After being driven home by Grant, Miller drags his injured body into bed at 4:30 am, arousing suspicion in his wife. The next day, he is questioned by police detective Bryer ([[Tim Roth]]). Bryer is keen on arresting Robert for manslaughter and begins to put the pieces together. Brooke discovers the financial irregularities, realizes that she could be implicated and confronts her father.
Jimmy is arrested and placed before a [[grand jury]] but still refuses to admit to helping Miller. Miller once again contemplates turning himself in. Even though Jimmy is about to go to prison, Miller tells Jimmy that investors are depending on him and that waiting for the sale to close before coming forward would serve the greater good. Eventually, the sale is closed, but Robert finds a way to avoid being charged. He proves that Bryer had fabricated evidence. The case against Jimmy is dismissed, and the detective is ordered not to go near him. Robert's wife tries to blackmail him with a separation agreement getting rid of his wealth. When Robert refuses to sign, his wife says that she will tell the police that he got into bed at 4:30 am on the night of the accident, bruised and [[bleeding]] but will tell them that he was there all night if he agrees to sign.
In the final scene, Robert addresses a banquet honoring him for his successful business, with his wife at his side and his daughter introducing him to the audience but their false embrace on the stage signifies that he has lost the respect and admiration of his daughter. As Robert approaches the podium to deliver his speech the screen cuts to black, leaving his decision ambiguous.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thewrap.com/movies/column-post/richard-gere-why-his-cheating-arbitrage-financier-bill-clinton-56736|title=Richard Gere: Why My Cheating 'Arbitrage' Financier Is Like Bill Clinton|first=Steve|last=Pond|work=The Wrap|accessdate=2012-12-23}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://movies.yahoo.com/movie/arbitrage/user-reviews/Richard+Gere+movie-56UKB42KYADOBOAAAR4ZB23W3Y.html|first=Jeannie|last=M|title=Richard Gere movie|work=Yahoo Movies|date=2012-09-26|accessdate=2012-12-23}}</ref>
==Cast== * [[Richard Gere]] as Robert Miller * [[Susan Sarandon]] as Ellen Miller * [[Tim Roth]] as Det. Bryer * [[Brit Marling]] as Brooke Miller * [[Laetitia Casta]] as Julie Cote * [[Nate Parker]] as Jimmy Grant * [[Stuart Margolin]] as Syd Felder * [[Chris Eigeman]] as Gavin Briar * [[Graydon Carter]] as James Mayfield * [[Bruce Altman]] as Chris Vogler
==Reception == === Box office ===
''Arbitrage'' was a worldwide box-office success and is the highest grossing "day-and-date" independently produced film of all time.{{citation needed|date=November 2016}}
Lionsgate and Roadside Attractions paid $2.1 million to acquire the United States rights of this film, and they spent around $3 million promoting the film's theatrical and VOD release. <ref>https://web.archive.org/web/20121103060111/http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/envelope/cotown/la-et-ct-arbitrage-vod-20121102,0,6330523.story</ref><ref>https://variety.com/2013/film/markets-festivals/film-buyers-show-dance-haul-moves-1118064551/</ref> The film went on grossing $7.9 million in the United States box office and $14 million in United States VOD sales. <ref>http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=arbitrage.htm</ref> <ref>http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/sundance-how-arbitrages-vod-gamble-412594</ref>
As of 2014, the film had grossed over $35,485,056 in the global box office.<ref>[http://boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=arbitrage.htm Box Office Mojo Arbitrage]. Retrieved 29 December 2014.</ref>
The film also outperformed financially in several areas: it set a record as the highest grossing "day-and-date" release of all time, meaning it outperformed all other films released simultaneously in theaters and "on-demand". It also opened to a per screen average in the United States in excess of $10,000, making it one of the highest per-screen average films of the year. It was the top film in Israel two weeks running and No. 3 in Spain two weeks running, nearing a Spanish theatrical gross of US$ 5 million. It broke independent box office records in many other countries including Australia, the United Arab Emirates, and Switzerland.{{citation needed|date=January 2015}}
=== Critical response === {{Anchor|Critics}} ''Arbitrage'' was praised by critics and has a rating of 87% on [[Rotten Tomatoes]] based on 151 reviews with the consensus: "Arbitrage is both a tense thriller and a penetrating character study, elevated by the strength of a typically assured performance from Richard Gere." Many critics pointed out Gere's "conflicted performance" as a "career-best", and cited the screenplay, ensemble acting, and direction as high quality.
=== Accolades === {{Anchor|Awards|Accolades}}
''Arbitrage'' was nominated for 7 awards and won 4.
Gere was nominated for the [[Golden Globe Award for Best Actor – Motion Picture Drama]] at the [[70th Golden Globe Awards]] for his performance in ''Arbitrage''.
The film won the following awards: [[National Board of Review]] - "Top 10 Independent Films," [[African American Film Critics Association]] - "Best Supporting Actor: Nate Parker," [[Hamptons International Film Festival]] - "Breakthrough Performer: Nate Parker"
It was also nominated for: [[Chicago Film Critics Society]] - "Most Promising Filmmaker: Nicholas Jarecki", Phoenix Film Critics Society - "Best Original Screenplay: Nicholas Jarecki", [[San Sebastian International Film Festival]] - "Golden Shell: Nicholas Jarecki"

{{Unreferenced|date=December 2009}} A '''bankruptcy remote''' [[company (law)|company]] is a company within a [[corporate group]] whose [[bankruptcy]] has as little economic impact as possible on other entities within the group. A bankruptcy remote company is often a [[single-purpose entity]].
In practice, due to the concept of [[limited liability]], most companies in developed [[legal system]]s will be ''de facto'' bankruptcy remote from other members of the group (except in limited circumstances where [[creditor]]s are permitted to [[piercing the corporate veil|pierce the corporate veil]]). However, in financial structuring, references to bankruptcy remoteness usually imply additional steps being taken to protect group members from attendant liability, such as by using an [[orphan structure]] to remove the legal ownership of the bankruptcy remote vehicle from the group, whilst retaining the economic benefits of it. Such structures are used where the vehicle's activities may give liability to the group as a whole, for example, under certain [[environmental protection]] legislation, or in relation to [[tax]] liabilities in certain countries.
==External links== * [http://www.americanbar.org/content/dam/aba/events/real_property_trust_estate/symposia/2004/moskowitz_paper_1_special_purpose_bankruptcy_remote_entities.pdf Special-Purpose Bankruptcy-Remote Entities] - [[American Bar Association]]

{{ infobox Politician | name = Bruno Bonnell | image = Bruno Bonnell.jpg | office = Member of the [[National Assembly (France)|National Assembly]] for [[Rhône's 6th constituency]] | term_start = 21 June 2017 | term_end = | predecessor = [[Pascale Crozon]] | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1958|10|06|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Algiers]], [[Algeria]] | nationality = [[French nationality law|French]] | party = [[La République En Marche!]] | alma_mater = [[CPE Lyon]]
[[Paris Dauphine University]] }} '''Bruno Bonnell''' (born 6 October 1958) is a [[France|French]] businessman. He is co-founder of [[Infogrames Entertainment SA]]. ==Career== He began his career on the [[Thomson SA|Thomson]] [[Thomson TO7|TO7]], one of the earliest French-produced home computers, before founding [[Infogrames]] in June 1983. He founded this company at age 25 with [[Christophe Sapet]] and [[Thomas Schmider]]. He was [[chairman]] and [[chief creative officer]] of the company from 1983 to 5 April 2007. He was also [[chief executive officer]]; a position he held from 1983 until a stockholder vote in 2003 showed a lack of confidence in his management of the company’s debts. He stepped down as CEO of [[Atari]] (while retaining his other two positions in IESA) in 2004 to be replaced by [[James Caparro]], although he took up the position again on a temporary basis when Caparro resigned in June 2005. On 5 September 2006, [[David Pierce (CEO)|David Pierce]] was appointed as new CEO of [[Atari]].{{cite web|url=http://ds.ign.com/articles/730/730521p1.html |title=Games, reviews, previews, nieuws, tips, video's en trailers - IGN Benelux |publisher=Ds.ign.com |date= |accessdate=2013-11-13}} In 1995, Bonnell was elected president of the [[Syndicat des Editeurs de Logiciels de Loisirs]] (SELL), a French game developer association. He worked together with French broadcaster [[Canal Plus]] to create the television channel [[Game One]], which was specifically aimed at a gaming audience. Intended as a European channel, Game One broadcast in the [[French language]]. He spearheaded takeovers of many smaller (and a few larger) development studios over the 1980s and 1990s, most notably British development house [[Ocean Software]] and Atari, as well as [[GT Interactive]], [[Accolade (company)|Accolade]], [[Gremlin Graphics]] and [[Hasbro Interactive]]. These companies were integrated into the Infogrames infrastructure. Their brand names were abandoned, with the exception of [[Atari]], which Bonnell felt had value. For this reason Infogrames began using the Atari brand on games published around Christmas 2001 and renamed itself to Atari, Inc. in the US in 2003. Beyond his involvement in Infogrames & Atari, Bonnell is also a shareholder in [[Lyon]]'s soccer team; the [[Olympique Lyonnais]]. On 5 April 2007, he resigned from his positions at [[Atari]] and [[Infogrames]].{{cite web|url=http://www.gamespot.com/pages/news/story.php?sid%3D6168631%26part%3Drss%26subj%3D6168631 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2007-04-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930204637/http://www.gamespot.com/pages/news/story.php?sid=6168631&part=rss&subj=6168631 |archivedate=2007-09-30 |df= }} On the day of the announcement of his departure IESA's shares jumped 24%.{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/technology-media-telco-SP/idUSL052812320070405 |title=Infogrames shares shine after chairman leaves | Reuters |publisher=Reuters In June 2008, he joined [[zSlide]], a company based near Paris. As of 2013 he was working for Robopolis,{{cite web |url=http://www.20minutes.fr/article/399897/Web-Bruno-Bonnell-Les-robots-vont-transformer-notre-quotidien-de-la-meme-maniere-que-les-telephones-portables.php |archive-url=https://archive.is/20100425063931/http://www.20minutes.fr/article/399897/Web-Bruno-Bonnell-Les-robots-vont-transformer-notre-quotidien-de-la-meme-maniere-que-les-telephones-portables.php |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2010-04-25 |title=Bruno Bonnell: «Les robots vont transformer notre quotidien, de la même manière que les téléphones portables |publisher=20minutes.fr |date=2010-05-31 |accessdate=2013-11-13 }} a Lyon-based robot distributor. On 31 May 2012, Bruno Bonnell is elected as President of the EMLyon Business School Board.{{cite web |url=http://www.em-lyon.com/fr/emlyon-enseignement-entrepreneuriat/business-school/actualites-grande-ecole-management/Manuel/Bruno-Bonnell-elu-President-du-Conseil-d-Administration-d-EMLYON-Business-School |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-04-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140422223024/http://www.em-lyon.com/fr/emlyon-enseignement-entrepreneuriat/business-school/actualites-grande-ecole-management/Manuel/Bruno-Bonnell-elu-President-du-Conseil-d-Administration-d-EMLYON-Business-School |archivedate=2014-04-22 |df= }} EMLyon is a business school in Lyon, created in 1872. On 11 May 2017, he was invested by [[En Marche!]] to contest [[Rhône's 6th constituency]], against minister [[Najat Vallaud-Belkacem]], in the [[French legislative election, 2017|legislative elections]].{{cite news|author=Catherine Lagrange|title=Législatives : Bruno Bonnell en marche contre Najat Vallaud-Belkacem|url=http://www.lepoint.fr/legislatives/legislatives-bruno-bonnell-en-marche-contre-najat-vallaud-belkacem-11-05-2017-2126672_3408.php|newspaper=Le Point|date=11 May 2017|accessdate=11 May 2017}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{moby developer|id=634|name=Bruno Bonnell's profile}} *[http://corporate.infogrames.com/IESA/pressreleases_story.html?sid=783 IESA Press Release]{{dead link|date=November 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} *{{cite web |url=http://www.gamepro.fr/actualites/47381/bruno-bonnell-zslide/ |title=Bruno Bonnell conseille zSlide | PCWorld.fr |publisher=Gamepro.fr |date= |accessdate=2013-11-13 |language=fr |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130213105114/http://www.gamepro.fr/actualites/47381/bruno-bonnell-zslide/ |archivedate=2013-02-13 |df= }} {{Group Danone}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Bonnell, Bruno}} [[Category:1958 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:French businesspeople]] [[Category:Atari people]] [[Category:People from Algiers]] [[Category:French people of Catalan descent]] [[Category:Paris Dauphine University alumni]] [[Category:La République En Marche politicians]] [[Category:Deputies of the 15th National Assembly of the French Fifth Republic]] [[Category:Chevaliers of the Légion d'honneur]]

[[File:Coloured cast acrylic by Midton Acrylics.jpg|thumb|Cast Acrylic]] [[File:Coloured acrylic transparency by Midton Acrylics.jpg|thumb|Cast Acrylic]] [[File:Coloured acrylic water effect by Midton Acrylics.jpg|thumb|Cast Acrylic]]
'''Cast Acrylic''' is a form of [[Poly(methyl methacrylate)|poly(methyl methacrylate)]] (PMMA). It is formed by casting the [[monomer]], [[methyl methacrylate]], mixed with [[Radical initiator|initiators]] and possibly other additives into a form or mold. Sheet and rod stock are generated by casting into static forms, while tubing is done in rotational molds.
== Advantages ==
It has better thermal stability, higher resistance to crazing (when a network of very small cracks form) when exposed to solvents, wider thermoforming range than extruded acrylic. Cast acrylic has better ability to be reworked hot and it is known for its superior surface finish and optical properties. Also cast acrylic is more scratch resistant than extruded acrylic. Cast acrylic is also preferred over extruded in applications that require machining, such as turning on Engine Lathe or milling/drilling. Extruded acrylic, with far less thermal stability, tends to melt and clog cutting tools. Even with slow speeds and lots of coolant, extruded acrylic does not produce the surface finish and tight tolerances achievable with cast acrylic.
== Usage ==
This type of acrylic is often used for aquariums, awards, financial tombstones, trophies, corporate gifts, and other products that require shaping or machining. It tends to be more clear and made to a higher quality standard, but in doing so makes it more expensive than extruded acrylic.

{{marriage|[[Nigella Lawson]]|2003|2013|reason=div}} | children = 1 daughter, Phoebe | website = {{url|http://charlessaatchi.co.uk/}} }} '''Charles Saatchi ''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|s|ɑː|tʃ|iː}}; {{lang-ar|تشارلز ساعتجي}}; born 9 June 1943) is an Iraqi-British Jewish businessman and the co-founder with his brother [[Maurice Saatchi, Baron Saatchi|Maurice]] of advertising agency [[Saatchi & Saatchi]]. The brothers led the business – the world's largest [[advertising agency]] in the 1980s – until they were forced out in 1995. In the same year, the brothers formed a new agency called [[M&C Saatchi]]. Saatchi is also known for his art collection and for owning [[Saatchi Gallery]], and in particular for his sponsorship of the [[Young British Artists]] (YBAs), including [[Damien Hirst]] and [[Tracey Emin]]. ==Early life== Charles Saatchi is the second of four sons born to [[Nathan Saatchi]] and Daisy Ezer, a wealthy [[Iraqi Jewish]] family in [[Baghdad]], [[Iraq]]. The name "[[Saatchi (disambiguation)|Saatchi]]" saatçi (''sā'ātchi''), which means "watchmaker", originates from Turkish. {{cite book |last=Alkalesi |first=Yasin M. |chapter=Nouns of Occupations with Suffixes -chi and -chiyya |title=Modern Iraqi Arabic: A Textbook |publisher=Georgetown University Press |date=October 2006 |isbn=978-1-58901-130-4}} Saatchi's brothers are David (born 1937), [[Maurice Saatchi|Maurice]] (born 1946) and Philip (born 1953).Goldman – Conflicting Accounts In 1947 his father, a textile merchant, anticipated the flight that tens of thousands of Iraqi Jews would soon make to avoid persecution and relocated his family to [[Finchley]], north London.{{cite news|url=http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/visual_arts/article5817312.ece|title=The Saturday interview: Charles Saatchi|last=Thomson|first=Alice |author2=[[Rachel Sylvester]] |date=28 February 2009|publisher=Times Online|accessdate=24 November 2009 | location=London}}{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/in_depth/uk/2000/newsmakers/2124645.stm|title=Charles Saatchi: Artful adman|last=Jones|first=Chris |date=12 July 2002|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=24 November 2009}} Nathan Saatchi purchased two textile mills in north London and after a time rebuilt a thriving business. Eventually the family would settle into an eight-bedroom house in Hampstead Lane, [[Highgate]]. Saatchi attended [[Christ's College (Finchley)|Christ's College]], a grammar school in Finchley, north London. During this time, he developed an obsession with US [[popular culture|pop culture]], including the music of [[Elvis Presley]], [[Little Richard]] and [[Chuck Berry]]. He has described as "life-changing" the experience of viewing a [[Jackson Pollock]] painting at the [[Museum of Modern Art]] in New York. He then progressed to study at the [[London College of Communication]].{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/4730049/Adventures-in-Saatchiland.html|title=Adventures in Saatchiland|last=Gleadell |first=Colin |date=31 December 2001|publisher=Telegraph|accessdate=25 November 2009 | location=London}} ==Advertising career== ===Early career=== In 1965, Saatchi undertook his first advertising role as a copywriter in the London office of [[Benton & Bowles]], where he met Doris Lockhart (later his first wife).{{cite news | last=Darwent |first=Charles |date=17 October 1998 |title=Pieces From a Confessional |url= https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/pieces-from-a-confessional-1179187.html |access-date=9 February 2016}} Saatchi paired up with [[art director]] Ross Cramer and they worked as a team at [[Collett Dickenson Pearce]] and John Collins & Partners before leaving in 1967 to open creative consultancy Cramer Saatchi.{{cite book |last=Tungate |first=Mark |date=2007 |title=Adland: A Global History of Advertising |publisher=Kogan Page Publishers |page=94|isbn=0749464313}} Unusually for a creative consultancy, they took on employees: [[Bartle Bogle Hegarty|John Hegarty]] – previously Saatchi's art director at Benton & Bowles, who would later go on to run rival agency [[Bartle Bogle Hegarty]] – and [[Jeremy Sinclair]], who as of 2016 still retains a senior role at M&C Saatchi.{{cite book |last=Pasiuk |first=Laurie |date=2005 |title=Vault Guide to the Top Advertising & PR Employers |publisher=Vault Inc |page=135 |isbn=1581313837}} In addition to offering consulting with ad agencies they also took on some clients directly. ===Saatchi and Saatchi=== In 1970, he started the advertising agency Saatchi & Saatchi with his brother Maurice, which by 1986 – following its acquisition of advertising firm [[Ted Bates (advertising firm)|Ted Bates]] – had grown to be the largest ad agency in the world, with over 600 offices.{{cite web |url=http://artobserved.com/2009/01/charles-saatchi-and-bbc-set-to-launch-reality-tv-show-to-discover-next-generation-of-artistic-talent/ |title= Charles Saatchi and BBC set to launch reality tv show to discover next generation of artistic talent |date=27 January 2009 | access-date=9 February 2016}}{{cite web |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/avidan/2012/06/21/advertising-shoots-itself-in-the-foot-again/#2db39ef281d0 |title= Advertising Shoots Itself in the Foot. Again.|date=21 June 2012 | access-date=23 March 2016}} Successful campaigns in the UK included [[Silk Cut]]'s advertisements in preparation for the ban on named tobacco advertising, and the [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative Party's]] [[United Kingdom general election, 1979|1979 general election]] victory – led by [[Margaret Thatcher]] through the slogan "[[Labour Isn't Working]]".{{cite book |last= Gibson|first=J |date=2005 |title=Art and Advertising |location=London |publisher=I.B. Tauris & Co Ltd |page=54 |isbn=1850435855}}{{cite web |url= https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/they-said-labour-isnt-working-now-saatchi-saatchi-works-for-labour-744790.html |title= they said Labour isn't working. Now Saatchi & Saatchi works for Labour|last1=McSmith |first1=Andy |date=13 September 2007 |website= |publisher= |access-date=9 February 2016}} ===M&C Saatchi=== At the turn of 1995, Saatchi and his brother left the agency, and together founded the rival M&C Saatchi agency, taking with them many of their management and creative staff, as well as a number of clients – including [[British Airways]].{{cite news |author= |date=4 January 1996 |title=British Airways head praises Maurice Saatchi |newspaper=Reuters |location= }} ==Art== [[File:SaatchiGallery.jpg|thumb|The Saatchi Gallery's new premises in Chelsea, which opened in October 2008.]] In 1969, at age 26, Saatchi purchased his first work of art by [[Sol LeWitt]], a New York minimalist. Saatchi initially patronised the [[Lisson Gallery]] in Marylebone, London, which specialised in American minimalist works. He later purchased an entire show by [[Robert Mangold]]. In the early 1980s, Saatchi purchased a {{convert|30000|sqft|m2|abbr=on}} cement-floored and steel-girded warehouse at 98A Boundary Road in the residential London suburb of [[St. John's Wood]]. The building was transformed by architect Max Gordon into the [[Saatchi Gallery]], which was subsequently opened to the public in February 1985 to exhibit the art Saatchi had collected.{{cite journal |last= Frascina|first=Francis |date=June 2013 |title=Thatcher's Legacy |journal= Art Monthly|volume= 367|page=4}}{{cite book |last= Goldman|first= K|date=1997 |title= Conflicting Accounts: The Creation and Crash of the Saatchi and Saatchi Advertising Empire |location=New York |publisher= Touchstone|page= 149|isbn=0684815710}} At one point the Saatchi collection contained 11 works by [[Donald Judd]], 21 by [[Sol LeWitt]], 23 by [[Anselm Kiefer]], 17 [[Andy Warhol]]s and 27 by [[Julian Schnabel]]. His taste has mutated from American abstraction and minimalism to the [[Young British Artists]] (YBAs), whose work he first saw at Goldsmith's Art School. At the YBAs' 1990 [[East Country Yard Show|''Gambler'']] exhibition, Saatchi bought [[Damian Hirst]]'s first major 'animal' installation, ''A Thousand Years''.{{cite book |last=Anderson |first=Jamie |date=2010 |title=The Fine Art of Success: How Learning Great Art Can Create Great Business |publisher=Wiley |page= |isbn=978-0-470-66106-2}} In 1991, he acquired major artworks by Hirst and [[Marc Quinn]], becoming instrumental in launching their careers. His renown as a patron peaked in 1997, when part of his collection was shown at the [[Royal Academy]] as the exhibition ''[[Sensation exhibition|Sensation]]'', which travelled to Berlin and New York causing headlines and some offence (for example, to the families of children murdered by [[Myra Hindley]], who was portrayed in one of the works), and consolidating the position of Hirst, [[Tracey Emin|Emin]] and other YBAs.{{cite news |last=Kino |first=Carol |date=22 October 1995 |title=Art; Not One Drop of British Reserve |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/22/arts/art-not-one-drop-of-british-reserve.html |newspaper= The New York Times|location= |access-date=9 February 2016}} In 2009, he published the book ''My Name Is Charles Saatchi And I Am An Artoholic''.{{ISBN|0-7148-5747-5}} Subtitled "Everything You Need To Know About Art, Ads, Life, God And Other Mysteries And Weren't Afraid To Ask", it presents Saatchi's answers to a number of questions submitted by members of the public and journalists. From November to December 2009, he had a television programme on the [[BBC]] called ''[[School of Saatchi]]'' in which he gave young aspiring artists an opportunity to showcase their work. He made no appearance in the programme, only communicating through an assistant. In July 2010, Charles Saatchi announced he would be donating the Saatchi Gallery and over 200 works of art to the British public.Hewage, Tim. [http://news.sky.com/skynews/Home/UK-News/Art-Collector-Charles-Saatchi-Gives-His-London-Gallery-And-Its-Entire-Art-Collection-To-Public/Article/201007115657838?lpos=UK_News_First_Home_Article_Teaser_Region_9&lid=ARTICLE_15657838_Art_Collector_Charles_Saatchi_Gives_His_London_Gallery_And_Its_Entire_Art_Collection_To_Public "Saatchi Donates Art Collection To Public"], [[Sky News]], 1 July 2010.{{cite news| url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/culturecritics/richarddorment/7866615/Charles-Saatchis-donation.html | location=London | work=The Daily Telegraph | title=Charles Saatchi's donation | first=Richard | last=Dorment | date=1 July 2010}} The Saatchi Gallery featured in a list of the most visited art museums in the world, based on an attendance survey for 2014, compiled by ''The Art Newspaper,'' with 1,505,608 visitors. In the same survey, the gallery was shown to have hosted 15 of the 20 most visited exhibitions in London over the last 5 years.{{Cite news|url = http://www.museus.gov.br/wp-content/uploads/2015/04/TheArtNewspaper_Ranking2014.pdf|title = Instituto Brasileiro de Museus|last = |first = |date = 14 January 2016|work = Instituto Brasileiro de Museus|access-date = 14 January 2016|via = }} ==Publications== Books published by Charles Saatchi include: ''Looking Over Your Opponent's Shoulder.'' (1998) Bow Publications. {{ISBN|0861291484}} ''Charles Saatchi: Question.'' (2010) Phaidon. {{ISBN|9780714857091}} ''My Name Is Charles Saatchi And I Am An Artoholic.'' (2012) Phaidon. {{ISBN|9781861543332}} ''Be the Worst You Can be: Life's Too Long for Patience and Virtue.'' (2012) Abrams. {{ISBN|9781419703737}} ''The Naked Eye. (2013) Booth-Clibborn Editions.'' {{ISBN|9781861543400}} ''Babble.'' (2013) Booth-Clibborn Editions. {{ISBN|9781861543370}} ''Known Unknowns.'' (2014) Booth-Clibborn Editions. {{ISBN|9781861543608}} ''DEAD, A Celebration of Mortality.'' (2015) Booth-Clibborn Editions. {{ISBN|9781861543592}} ''Beyond Belief: Racist, Sexist, Rude, Crude and Dishonest: The Golden Age of Madison Avenue.'' (2015) Booth-Clibborn Editions. {{ISBN|9781861543721}} ==Television== ''The Real Saatchis: Masters of Illusion'' (1999, Channel 4) {{cite news |last=Solomon |first=Deborah|date=26 September 1999 |title=The Collector|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1999/09/26/magazine/the-collector.html |newspaper= The New York Times |location= |access-date=9 February 2016}}{{cite web |url=http://www.bfi.org.uk/films-tv-people/4ce2b83181c38 |title= The Real Saatchis Masters of Illusion (1999) |author= |date= |website=bfi.org.uk |publisher= |access-date=9 February 2016 }} ''[[School of Saatchi]]'' (2009, BBC Two){{cite news |author= |title=School of Saatchi, BBC Two, review |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/tvandradio/6672343/School-of-Saatchi-BBC-Two-review.html |newspaper=The Telegraph|location= |date=27 November 2009 |access-date=9 February 2016}} == Philanthropy == He and his brother founded an independent [[Orthodox Jewish|Jewish]] synagogue, named [[Saatchi Shul]] in [[Maida Vale]], London, England, in 1998, in honour of their parents. In December 1998, Saatchi donated 130 artworks to a [[Christie's]] auction that raised £1.7 million, creating scholarship bursaries at four London art schools. In February 1999, he gave an additional 100 pieces of artwork from his collection to the [[Arts Council of Great Britain]]. In July 2010, Charles Saatchi announced he would be donating the Saatchi Gallery and over 200 works of art to the British public. The donation was estimated to be worth £30 million.{{cite news |last=Nikkah |first=Roya |date=19 August 2012 |title=Charles Saatchi's £30 million gift to the nation goes begging |newspaper=The Telegraph |location= }} He has donated over 100 works to the [[Tate]] Gallery, Art for Hospitals and the Arts Council. ==Personal life== According to the ''[[Times Online]]'', Saatchi is "reclusive", even hiding from clients when they visited his agency's offices and, as of February 2009, has only ever granted two newspaper interviews.{{cite news|url=http://www.saatchi-gallery.co.uk/charlesqa/qa.htm|title=Readers' questions|publisher=The Sunday Telegraph|accessdate=24 November 2009}} He does not attend his own exhibition openings; when asked why by the ''[[Sunday Telegraph]]'', he replied: "I don't go to other people's openings, so I extend the same courtesy to my own." In ''[[Sunday Times Rich List 2009|The Sunday Times Rich List]]'' ranking of the wealthiest people in the UK, he was grouped with his brother Maurice, with an estimated joint fortune of £120 million.{{cite news|url=http://business.timesonline.co.uk/richlist-app/index.php?pageID=19|title=Rich List 2009|year=2009|publisher=Times Online|accessdate=26 November 2009 | location=London}} ===Marriages=== Saatchi first met Doris Lockhart Dibley (as she was then known) in 1965 when she was a copy group head above him at Benton & Bowles. She was a native of [[Memphis, Tennessee]], USA and Kevin Goldman describes her as "a sophisticated woman who spoke several languages, knew a great deal about art and wine and who had graduated from [[Smith College]] and the [[Sorbonne]]". She became known during their marriage as an art and design journalist, with particular knowledge of American art and [[minimalism]]. They lived together for six yearsGoldman, p.39 before getting married in 1973 and divorcing in 1990.{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/pieces-from-a-confessional-1179187.html|title=Pieces from a confessional|last=Darwent |first=Charles |date=18 October 1998|publisher=The Independent|accessdate=24 November 2009 | location=London}} Saatchi's second wife was Kay Hartenstein (to whom he was married from 1990{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/13/style/chronicle-778490.html?pagewanted=1|title=Chronicle|date=13 August 1990|work=The New York Times|edition=New York|page=B6|publisher=The New York Times|last=Heller Anderson|first=Susan|accessdate=26 February 2010}} to 2001{{cite news|url=http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/visual_arts/article4371916.ece|title=Kay Saatchi on life after Charles Saatchi|last=Dougary|first=Ginny|work=The Times|publisher=Times Newspapers|date=26 July 2008|accessdate=26 February 2010 | location=London}}) an American [[Condé Nast Publications|Condé Nast]] advertising executive from [[Little Rock, Arkansas]]. Together they have a daughter, Phoebe.{{cite news |last=Wentz |first=Laurel |date=28 February 2000 |title=Saatchi at 5: After a stormy beginning, M&C Saatchi has crafted success in London, but the US remains elusive |newspaper=Advertising Age |location= }} Saatchi married his third wife, British journalist, author and cook [[Nigella Lawson]],[http://www.bbc.co.uk/pressoffice/pressreleases/stories/2003/10_october/10/jr_nigella.shtml "Jonathan Ross cooks up a storm with Nigella Lawson"]. ''[[BBC]] Press Office'', 10 October 2003; retrieved 30 September 2007. having drawn disapproval when she moved in with him nine months after her previous husband's death.Sands, Sarah. [http://www.dailymail.co.uk/femail/article-420003/I-dont-want-kitchen-blow-sex-doll.html I don't want to be some kitchen blow-up sex doll]. ''[[Daily Mail]]'', 1 December 2006; retrieved 29 July 2012. In January 2011, Saatchi and Lawson moved from their former home in Belgravia to a new home in Chelsea, London. This was a double fronted seven-bedroom villa converted from its former use as a warehouse and 200 metres from Saatchi's contemporary art gallery in King's Road, London. They lived with her two children Cosima and Bruno, as well as Phoebe.Hilton, Beth. [http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/showbiz/a88242/lawson-wont-leave-children-a-penny.html Lawson 'won't leave children a penny']. [[Digital Spy]], 29 January 2008. Retrieved on 31 January 2008.{{cite news|last=Jones|first=Sam|title=Nigella Lawson and Charles Saatchi granted divorce in 70-second hearing|url=https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2013/jul/31/nigella-lawson-charles-saatchi-divorce?CMP=twt_fd|accessdate=31 July 2013|newspaper=The Guardian|date=31 July 2013}} In June 2013, while dining at Scott's, a London seafood restaurant, Saatchi was photographed with his hand around Lawson's throat.Victoria Ward [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/crime/10123316/Nigella-Lawson-attacked-by-husband-at-restaurant.html "Nigella Lawson 'attacked by husband' at restaurant"], telegraph.co.uk, 16 June 2013{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2347086/Nigella-Lawsons-throat-attack-ordeal-Charles-Saatchi-momentary-tiff.html|title=Nigella Lawson's throat attack ordeal Charles Saatchi momentary tiff|publisher=Daily Mail | location=London|first=Neil|last=Sears|date=23 June 2013}} The day after the pictures were published, Saatchi said they were misleading and depicted only a "playful tiff". In early July of the same year it was announced that the couple were to divorce.[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-23216575 "Charles Saatchi and Nigella Lawson to divorce"], BBC News, 7 July 2013 Lawson cited ongoing unreasonable behaviour in her divorce petition. On 31 July 2013, seven weeks after the incident, Saatchi and Lawson were granted a [[decree nisi]]. They reached a private financial settlement. ''[[R v Grillo and Grillo]]'', a trial for fraud involving the former couple's two Italian-born personal assistants, sisters Elisabetta and Francesca Grillo, began on 27 November 2013.[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-london-25122111 "Nigella Lawson and Charles Saatchi marriage 'secrecy'"], BBC News, 27 November 2013 ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==Further reading== * Hatton, Rita and Walker, John A. ''Supercollector: A Critique of Charles Saatchi'', Institute of Artology, 2005. {{ISBN|0-9545702-2-7}} * Kent, Sarah. ''Shark Infested Waters: The Saatchi Collection of British Art in the 90s'', Philip Wilson Publishers Ltd, 2003. {{ISBN|0-85667-584-9}} * Goldman, Kevin ''Conflicting Accounts – The Creation & Crash of the Saatchi & Saatchi Empire'', Simon & Schuster, New York, 1997. {{ISBN|0-684-83553-3}} ==External links== *[http://www.saatchi-gallery.co.uk The Saatchi Gallery] *{{Worldcat id|lccn-nr88-12051}} *{{NYTtopic|people/s/charles_saatchi}} *[http://arts.guardian.co.uk/features/story/0,,1865768,00.html ''Guardian'' Interview], 6 September 2006 *[http://women.timesonline.co.uk/tol/life_and_style/women/the_way_we_live/article7086612.ece Saatchi answers reader's questions on Times Online], 4 April 2010 *[https://www.nytimes.com/2010/07/02/arts/design/02saatchi.html?adxnnl=1&ref=arts&adxnnlx=1278054088-JAcPp6wpYrF6DoHhWaLKqQ Saatchi Says He'll Give Britain His Gallery and Over $37 Million in Art], ''[[The New York Times]]'', 1 July 2010 {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2016}} {{Young British Artists}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Saatchi, Charles}} [[Category:1943 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Advertising people]] [[Category:Alumni of the University of the Arts]] [[Category:British art collectors]] [[Category:British businesspeople]] [[Category:British Jews]] [[Category:British people of Iraqi-Jewish descent]] [[Category:British people of Iraqi descent]] [[Category:Businesspeople in advertising]] [[Category:Iraqi businesspeople]] [[Category:Iraqi emigrants to the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Iraqi Jews]] [[Category:Museum founders]] [[Category:Naturalised citizens of the United Kingdom]] [[Category:People from Baghdad]] [[Category:People educated at Christ's College, Finchley]] [[Category:Saatchi family]]

{{more citations needed|date=May 2016}} {{Infobox company | name = Chevron Phillips Chemical | logo = | type = Private Company | foundation = 2000 | location = [[The Woodlands, Texas]], United States | area_served = | key_people = Mark Lashier
([[President (corporate title)|President]] and [[CEO]]) | industry = Petrochemical | products = Aromatics, Drilling Specialties, K-Resin® SBC, Normal Alpha Olefins, Olefins, Polyalphaoelfins, [[Polyethylene]], Specialty Chemicals | production = | services = | revenue = {{profit}} $13.416 billion (2014) | operating_income = {{increase}} | net_income = {{profit}} $3.288 billion (2014) | assets = {{increase}} $9.00 billion (2014) | equity = {{increase}} $10.260 billion (2014){{cite web |url=http://www.cpchem.com/en-us/company/financialinfo/pages/default.aspx |title=Financial Information |accessdate=2015-11-11 |publisher=cpchem.com}} | owner = | num_employees = 5,000 (December 2014) | parent = [[Chevron Corporation|Chevron]] and [[Phillips 66]] | divisions = | subsid = | homepage = {{url|cpchem.com}} | footnotes = | intl = }} '''Chevron Phillips Chemical''' is a [[petrochemical company]] jointly owned by [[Chevron Corporation]] and [[Phillips 66]]. The company was formed July 1, 2000 by merging the chemicals operations of both Chevron Corporation and [[Phillips Petroleum Company]]. As equally-owned company, it is governed by a board of directors composed of two members from each of the parent companies. The company was actually named in a coin toss to determine which parent company name would be first and which would be last.{{cite news |title=Coin toss decides company name |url=http://www.lubbockonline.com/stories/041800/bus_041800085.shtml |publisher=The Lubbock Avalanche-Journal |date=2000-04-18 |accessdate=2008-03-07 }} Chevron Phillips is headquartered in [[The Woodlands, Texas]], a northern suburb of Houston, and is a major producer of [[ethylene]], [[propylene]], [[polyethylene]], [[Alpha-olefin]]s, [[Polyalphaolefins]], [[aromatic compound]]s and a range of [[specialty chemicals]]. == Operations == As of the end of 2014 the Company has 5,000 employees worldwide, US$9 billion in assets, and 36 manufacturing and research facilities in eight countries, including the United States, Belgium, China, Colombia, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Singapore, and South Korea. It has 24 facilities in 13 U.S. states.{{cite web |url=http://www.cpchem.com/en-us/company/Pages/worldwideoperations.aspx |title=Worldwide Operations |accessdate=2015-11-11 |publisher=cpchem.com}} ==Corporate affairs== The headquarters and offices for the Americas are in [[The Woodlands, Texas]]. Europe, Middle East, and Africa operations are based in Stockholm Building in Airport Plaza in [[Diegem]], [[Belgium]]. Asia/Pacific operations are based in Keppel Bay Tower in [[Singapore]]."[http://www.cpchem.com/en-us/pages/contactus.aspx Contact Us]." Chevron Phillips. Retrieved on September 6, 2017. "Headquarters 10001 Six Pines Drive The Woodlands, TX 77380" and "Chevron Phillips Chemical International N.V. Airport Plaza - Stockholm Building Leonardo Da Vincilaan 19 1831 Diegem Belgium" and "Chevron Phillips Chemicals Asia Pte. Ltd. [...] 5 Temasek Boulevard 05-01 Suntec Tower Five 038985 Singapore" ==See also== * [[Phillips disaster of 1989]] * [[Phillips explosion of 1999]] * [[Phillips explosion of 2000]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{official|www.cpchem.com}} {{Phillips 66}} [[Category:Oil companies of the United States]] [[Category:Petrochemical companies]] [[Category:Chevron Corporation]] [[Category:Phillips 66]] [[Category:Petroleum in Texas]] [[Category:Companies based in Houston]] [[Category:Non-renewable resource companies established in 2000]] [[Category:2000 establishments in Texas]] [[Category:Joint ventures]]

[[Tishman Speyer]] (10%) | references ={{emporis|114867}} | embedded = {{Infobox NRHP |embed=yes | name =Chrysler Building | nrhp_type = nhl | locmapin = New York City#New York#USA | map_caption = Location in New York City | architecture= [[Art Deco]] | designated_nrhp_type= December 8, 1976{{cite web|url=http://tps.cr.nps.gov/nhl/detail.cfm?ResourceId=1638&ResourceType=Building |title=Chrysler Building |website=National Historic Landmark summary listing |publisher=National Park Service |accessdate=April 20, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120505191205/http://tps.cr.nps.gov/nhl/detail.cfm?ResourceId=1638&ResourceType=Building |archivedate=May 5, 2012 |df=mdy }} | added = 1976{{NRISref|2007a|dateform=mdy}} | governing_body = private | refnum=76001237 | designated_other2_name = NYC Landmark | designated_other2_date = Exterior and interior: September 12, 1978{{sfn|Landmarks Preservation Commission|1978|p=1}} | designated_other2_abbr = NYCL | designated_other2_link = New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission | designated_other2_color = #FFE978 }}}} The '''Chrysler Building''' is an [[Art Deco]]–style [[Early skyscrapers|skyscraper]] located on the [[East Side (Manhattan)|East Side]] of [[Midtown Manhattan]] in [[New York City]], at the intersection of [[42nd Street (Manhattan)|42nd Street]] and [[Lexington Avenue (Manhattan)|Lexington Avenue]] in the [[Turtle Bay, Manhattan|Turtle Bay]] neighborhood of [[Manhattan]]. At {{convert|318.9|m|ft|0|order=flip|sp=us}}, the structure was the [[List of tallest buildings and structures#History|world's tallest building]] for 11 months before it was surpassed by the [[Empire State Building]] in 1931.{{cite web|url=http://ctbuh.org/AboutCTBUH/History/MeasuringTall/tabid/1320/language/en-US/Default.aspx |title=The History of Measuring Tall Buildings |website=Council on Tall Buildings and Urban Habitat |accessdate=May 1, 2012}} It is the tallest brick building in the world with a steel framework. {{As of|2018}}, the Chrysler is the [[List of tallest buildings in New York City|eighth-tallest building in the city]], tied with [[The New York Times Building]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.amny.com/real-estate/tallest-buildings-in-nyc-1.9216740|title=12 tallest skyscrapers in New York City|work=am New York|access-date=October 17, 2017|language=en}} Originally a project of real estate developer and former New York State Senator [[William H. Reynolds (senator)|William H. Reynolds]], the building was constructed by [[Walter Chrysler]], the head of the [[Chrysler|Chrysler Corporation]], and served as the corporation's headquarters from 1930 until the mid-1950s. The Chrysler Building's construction was characterized by a competition with [[40 Wall Street]] and the Empire State Building to become the world's tallest building. Although the Chrysler Building was built and designed specifically for the car manufacturer, the corporation did not pay for its construction and never owned it, as Walter Chrysler decided to pay for it himself, so that his children could inherit it. When the Chrysler Building opened, there were mixed reviews of the building's design, ranging from its being inane and unoriginal to that it was modernist and iconic. Perceptions of the building have slowly evolved into its now being seen as a paragon of the Art Deco architectural style; and in 2007, it was ranked ninth on the ''[[List of America's Favorite Architecture according to the AIA|List of America's Favorite Architecture]]'' by the [[American Institute of Architects]]. == History == === Context === [[File:Chrysler Building 2005 4.jpg|thumb|left|alt=A view of the Chrysler Building from the Empire State Building|The Chrysler Building from the [[Empire State Building]], both erected as part of New York City's 1920s building boom]] In the mid-1920s, [[New York metropolitan area|New York's metropolitan area]] surpassed [[Greater London|London's]] as the [[List of largest cities throughout history|world's most populous metropolitan area]].{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9iUhBQAAQBAJ&pg=PA197|title=America's Urban History|last=Boehm|first=Lisa Krissoff|last2=Corey|first2=Steven Hunt|publisher=Taylor & Francis|year=2014|isbn=978-1-317-81332-3|page=197|access-date=November 1, 2017}} New York City's [[New York metropolitan area|metropolitan area]] exceeded ten million by the early 1930s.{{cite web|url=http://demographia.com/db-nyuza1800.htm|title=New York Urbanized Area: Population & Density from 1800 (Provisional)|date=September 1, 2002|website=DEMOGRAPHIA|access-date=November 1, 2017}} The era was characterized by profound social and technological changes. Consumer goods such as radio, cinema, and the automobile—whose use grew exponentially in the 1920s—became widespread. In 1927, [[Walter Chrysler]]'s automotive company, the [[Chrysler|Chrysler Corporation]], became the third-largest car manufacturer in the United States, behind [[Ford Motor Company|Ford]] and [[General Motors]].{{Cite journal|last=|first=|date=June 2, 1928|title=Chrysler and Dodge Brothers Unite to Form Third Largest Producer|url=|journal=Automotive Industries|volume=|pages=853, 857|via=}}{{cite web|url=https://www.chryslerclub.org/walterp.html|title=The Chrysler Building 405 Lexington Avenue, Manhattan, New York City|last=Smale|first=Ian|date=December 25, 2008|website=Chrysler Products Club|access-date=November 1, 2017}} The following year he was named ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' magazine's "Person of the Year".{{Cite news|url=http://content.time.com/time/specials/packages/article/0,28804,2019712_2019703_2019660,00.html|title=Person of the Year: A Photo History - TIME|date=December 16, 2006|work=Time|access-date=November 1, 2017|language=en-US|issn=0040-781X}} The [[Roaring Twenties|economic boom of the 1920s]] and speculation in the real estate market fostered a wave of new skyscraper projects in New York City.{{cite web|url=http://skyscraper.org/EXHIBITIONS/TEN_TOPS/chrysler.php|title=The Skyscraper Museum: TIMES SQUARE, 1984: The Postmodern Moment WALKTHROUGH|last=Willis|first=Carol|date=|website=The Skyscraper Museum}} The Chrysler Building was built as part of an ongoing building boom that resulted in the city having the [[List of tallest buildings|world's tallest building]] from 1908 to 1974.{{Cite web|url=http://www.ctbuh.org/AboutCTBUH/History/MeasuringTall/tabid/1320/language/en-US/Default.aspx|title=History of Measuring Tall Buildings|last=|first=|date=December 2009|website=Council on Tall Buildings and Urban Habitat|language=en-US|access-date=November 1, 2017}} Following the end of [[World War I]], European and American architects came to see simplified design as the epitome of the modern era and [[Art Deco]] skyscrapers as symbolizing progress, innovation, and modernity. The [[1916 Zoning Resolution]] restricted the height that street-side exterior walls of New York City buildings could rise before needing to be [[Setback (architecture)|setback]] from the street.{{Efn|As per the 1916 Zoning Act, the wall of any given tower that faces a street could only rise to a certain height, proportionate to the street's width, at which point the building had to be set back by a given proportion. This system of setbacks would continue until the tower reaches a floor level in which that level's floor area was 25% that of the ground level's area. After that 25% threshold was reached, the building could rise without restriction.{{sfn|Kayden|Municipal Art Society|2000|p=8}} This law was modified in 1961.{{sfn|Kayden|Municipal Art Society|2000|pp=11–12}}|name=zoning}}{{cite web|url=https://www.buildings.com/article-details/articleid/3180/title/the-empire-state-building-an-innovative-skyscraper|title=The Empire State Building: An Innovative Skyscraper|last=Penafiel|first=Karen|date=June 28, 2006|website=Buildings Review|access-date=November 1, 2017}} This led to the construction of Art Deco structures in New York City with significant setbacks, large volumes, and striking silhouettes that were often elaborately decorated.{{sfn|Curcio|2001|p=417}}{{cite web|url=http://untappedcities.com/2011/12/07/how-zoning-shaped-the-new-york-skyline/|title=How Zoning Shaped the New York Skyline|last=Young|first=Michelle|date=December 7, 2011|website=Untapped Cities|access-date=November 1, 2017}} Art Deco buildings were constructed for only a short period of time; but because that period was during the city's late-1920s real estate boom, the numerous skyscrapers built in the Art Deco style predominated in the city skyline, giving it the romantic quality seen in films and plays.{{Harvnb|Landmarks Preservation Commission|1978|p=3}} The Chrysler Building project was shaped by these circumstances. The land on which the Chrysler Building stands was donated to [[Cooper Union|The Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art]] in 1902.{{cite web|url=http://www.cooper.edu/cubuilds/news_20040818.html|title=Cooper Union and Chrysler Building|date=September 15, 2004|publisher=Cooper.edu|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100708221034/http://www.cooper.edu/cubuilds/news_20040818.html|archivedate=July 8, 2010|deadurl=yes|accessdate=September 27, 2010|df=mdy}}{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/02/13/business/13cooper.html|title=Smart Land Deals as a Cornerstone of Free Tuition|last=Gregor|first=Alison|date=February 13, 2008|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=February 15, 2016}} The site is roughly a [[trapezoid]] with a {{convert|201|ft|m|-long|adj=mid}} [[frontage]] on Lexington Avenue; a {{convert|167|ft|m|-long|adj=mid}} frontage on 42nd Street; and a {{convert|205|ft|m|-long|adj=mid}} frontage on 43rd Street.{{Cite news|url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1928/10/17/118344646.pdf|title=Chrysler Plans 68-Story Building in Midtown; $14,000,000 Edifice to Top Woolworth Tower|last=|first=|date=October 17, 1928|work=The New York Times|access-date=November 2, 2017|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}{{dead link|date=April 2018|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} The site bordered the old [[Boston Post Road]],{{cite web| title=Chrysler Building plot angle | website=JamesRobertWatson.com | url=http://www.jamesrobertwatson.com/chryslerslant.html | access-date=November 3, 2017}}{{cite web | title=OPEN HOUSE NEW YORK 2006 | website=Forgotten New York | date=October 7, 2006 | url=http://forgotten-ny.com/2006/10/open-house-new-york-2006/ | access-date=November 4, 2017}} which predated, and ran aslant of, the Manhattan street grid established by the [[Commissioners' Plan of 1811]]. As a result, the east side of the building's base is similarly aslant.{{cite book | last=Walsh | first=Kevin | title=Forgotten New York: Views of a Lost Metropolis | publisher=HarperCollins | year=2006 | isbn=978-0-06-114502-5 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ViZNSexza6MC | access-date=November 2, 2017 | page=171}} === Planning === [[File:Chryslerbldng42st.jpg|thumb|left|upright|A view of the Chrysler Building from 42nd Street]] Originally, the Chrysler Building was to be the Reynolds Building, a project of real estate developer and former New York State Senator [[William H. Reynolds (senator)|William H. Reynolds]].{{sfn|Landmarks Preservation Commission|1978|p=1}}{{cite news |title=The Silver Spire: How two men's dreams changed the skyline of New York |first=Claudia Roth |last=Pierpont |url=http://www.jayebee.com/discoveries/criticism/silver_spire.htm |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040825173238/http://www.jayebee.com/discoveries/criticism/silver_spire.htm |archivedate=August 25, 2004|magazine=[[The New Yorker]] |date=November 18, 2002 |accessdate=February 14, 2016}} Prior to his involvement in planning the building, Reynolds was best known for developing [[Coney Island]]'s [[Dreamland (amusement park)|Dreamland amusement park]]. When the amusement park was destroyed by fire in 1911, Reynolds turned his attention to Manhattan real estate, where he set out to build the tallest building in the world.{{sfn|Landmarks Preservation Commission|1978|p=1}}{{cite web|url=http://in-arch.net/NYC/nyc2a.html|title=NEW YORK SCRAPERS - ART DECO II|last=|first=|date=June 17, 2014|website=in-Arch.net|access-date=November 1, 2017}} In 1921, Reynolds rented a large plot of land at the corner of [[Lexington Avenue]] and 42nd Street with the intention of building a tall building on the site.{{sfn|Landmarks Preservation Commission|1978|p=1}} In 1927, after several years of delays, Reynolds hired the architect [[William Van Alen]] to build a forty-story building there.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2005/05/26/garden/for-the-architect-a-height-never-again-to-be-scaled.html|title=For the Architect, a Height Never Again to Be Scaled|last=Bascomb|first=Neal|date=May 26, 2005|work=The New York Times|access-date=November 1, 2017|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}} Van Alen was respected in his field for his work on the Albemarle Building at Broadway and 24th Street, designing it in collaboration with his partner [[H. Craig Severance]].{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/22/realestate/streetscapes-william-van-alen-an-architect-called-the-ziegfeld-of-his-profession.html|title=Streetscapes/William Van Alen; An Architect Called the 'Ziegfeld of His Profession'|last=Gray|first=Christopher|date=March 22, 1998|website=The New York Times|access-date=November 1, 2017}}{{sfn|Kingston|2017|p=97}} Van Alen and Severance complemented each other, with Van Alen being an original, imaginative architect and Severance being a shrewd businessperson who handled the firm's finances.{{sfn|Bascomb|2004|p=2}} However, the relationship between them became tense over disagreements on how best to run the firm. The breaking point came after a 1924 article, in the ''[[Architectural Review]]'', that praised the Albemarle Building's design, which the article attributed to Van Alen, while ignoring Severance's role altogether. The architects' partnership dissolved acrimoniously several months later, with lawsuits over the firm's clients and assets lasting over a year.{{sfn|Bascomb|2004|p=4}}{{sfn|Kingston|2017|p=109}} This ended up being decisive for the design of the future Chrysler Building, since Severance's more traditional architectural style would otherwise have restrained Van Alen's more modern outlook.{{sfn|Kingston|2017|pp=108–109}} === Design === By February 2, 1928, the proposed building's height had been increased to 54 stories, which would have made it the tallest building in Midtown.{{Cite news|url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1928/02/02/95549248.pdf|title=54-Story Skyscraper, Tallest in Midtown, Planned at Lexington Avenue and 42d Street|last=|first=|date=February 2, 1928|work=The New York Times|access-date=November 8, 2017|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}{{dead link|date=April 2018|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} The proposal was changed again two weeks later, with official plans for a 63-story building.{{Cite news|url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1928/02/16/91475150.pdf|title=SKYSCRAPER PLANS FILED.; 63-Story Offices to Rise on Lexington Av. Between 42d and 43d.|last=|first=|date=February 16, 1928|work=The New York Times|access-date=November 8, 2017|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}{{dead link|date=April 2018|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} A little more than a week after that, the plan was changed for the third time, with two additional stories added.{{Cite news|url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1928/02/25/109855379.pdf|title=TALLEST BUILDING IN WORLD IS PLANNED; Skyscraper of 64 Stories, 800 Feet in Height, to Be Built in Grand Central Zone.|last=|first=|date=February 25, 1928|work=The New York Times|access-date=November 8, 2017|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}{{dead link|date=April 2018|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} By this time, 42nd Street and Lexington Avenue were both hubs for construction activity, due to the removal of the [[IRT Third Avenue Line|Third Avenue Elevated's]] 42nd Street spur, which was seen as a blight on the area. The 52-story [[Chanin Building]], diagonally across the intersection from Reynolds's proposed building, was also under construction. Because of the elevated spur's removal, real estate speculators believed that Lexington Avenue would become the "Broadway of the East Side", causing a [[ripple effect]] that would spur developments farther east.{{Cite news|url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1928/03/04/95557551.pdf|title=BUILDING ACTIVITY ON LEXINGTON AV.; The World's Tallest Structure Planned for the Grand Central Zone. AVENUEDORMANT FOR YEARS Realty Values on the Increase as Large Plots Are Assembled for Improvement. A $12,000,000 Project. Old Parish House Passes. Seminary Leased Recently.|last=|first=|date=March 4, 1928|work=The New York Times|access-date=November 8, 2017|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}{{dead link|date=April 2018|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} In April 1928, Reynolds signed a 67-year lease for the plot and finalized the details of his ambitious project.{{sfn|Kingston|2017|p=146}} Van Alen's original design for the skyscraper called for a base whose first-floor showroom windows would be triple-height, and above would be 12 stories with glass-wrapped corners, to create the impression that the tower was floating in mid-air.{{cite news|url=http://fultonhistory.com/highlighter/highlight-for-xml?altUrl=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FNewspaper%252011%2FNew%2520York%2520Evening%2520Post%2FNew%2520York%2520NY%2520Evening%2520Post%25201928%2520Grayscale%2FNew%2520York%2520NY%2520Evening%2520Post%25201928%2520Grayscale%2520-%25205602.pdf|title=Reynolds Building Will Be Tallest Structure in World|work=New York Evening Post|page=12|date=July 28, 1929|accessdate=November 3, 2017|via=[[Fultonhistory.com]]}} Reynolds's main contribution to the building's design was his insistence that it have a metallic crown, despite Van Alen's initial opposition;{{sfn|Nash|McGrath|1999|p=63}} the metal-and-crystal crown would have looked like "a jeweled sphere" at night.{{sfn|Tauranac|2014|p=189}} Originally, the skyscraper would have risen {{convert|808|ft|m|0|sp=us}}, with 67 floors.{{Cite news|url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1928/07/29/121606495.pdf|title=GRAND CENTRAL ZONE TO HAVE TALLEST BUILDING IN WORLD|last=|first=|date=July 29, 1928|work=The New York Times|access-date=November 2, 2017|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}{{dead link|date=April 2018|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} These plans were approved in June 1928.{{Cite news|url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1928/06/06/91523940.pdf|title=APPROVE NEW SKYSCRAPER|last=|first=|date=June 6, 1928|work=The New York Times|access-date=November 2, 2017|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}{{dead link|date=April 2018|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} Van Alen's drawings were unveiled in the following August and published in a magazine run by the [[American Institute of Architects]] (AIA).{{sfn|Kingston|2017|pp=145}} Eventually, this design would prove too advanced and expensive for Reynolds. He instead devised an alternate design for the Reynolds Building, which was published in August 1928. The new design was much more conservative, with an [[Italianate architecture|Italianate]] dome that a critic compared to Governor [[Al Smith]]'s bowler hat, and a brick arrangement on the upper floors that simulated windows in the corners, a detail that remains in the current Chrysler Building. This design almost exactly reflected the shape, setbacks, and the layout of the windows of the current building, but with a different dome. === Construction and finalization of plans === With the design complete, groundbreaking for the Reynolds Building took place on September 19, 1928, but Reynolds did not have the means to carry on construction.{{sfn|Kingston|2017|p=161}} Reynolds sold the plot, lease, plans, and architect's services to Walter Chrysler for $2 million on October 15, 1928.{{sfn|Kingston|2017|p=161}} That same day, the Goodwin Construction Company began demolition of what had been built.{{sfn|Cobb|2010|p=109}} A contract was awarded on October 28,{{Cite news | title=Prizes for Building Workers In Novel Poster Safety Campaign |last=|first=|date=October 28, 1928|work=The New York Times|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}} and demolition was completed on November 9.{{sfn|Cobb|2010|p=109}} Chrysler's initial plans for the building were similar to Reynolds's, but with the 808-foot building having 68 floors instead of 67. The plans entailed a ground-floor [[Pedestrian zone|pedestrian arcade]], a [[facade]] of stone below the fifth floor, a [[Brickwork|brick]]-and-[[terracotta]] facade above, and a "three-story observation dome" with "bronze and glass" at the top. However, Chrysler wanted a more progressive design, and he worked with Van Alen to redesign the skyscraper to be {{convert|925|ft|m|abbr=on}} tall.{{sfn|Kingston|2017|p=164}} At the new height, Chrysler's building would be taller than the {{convert|792|ft|m|adj=on}} [[Woolworth Building]], a building in lower Manhattan that was the world's tallest at the time.{{cite news| last=Gray | first=Christopher | title=Streetscapes: 40 Wall Street; A Race for the Skies, Lost by a Spire | work=The New York Times| date=November 15, 1992 | url=https://www.nytimes.com/1992/11/15/realestate/streetscapes-40-wall-street-a-race-for-the-skies-lost-by-a-spire.html | access-date=November 3, 2017}} [[File:New York City Chrysler Building 02.jpg|thumb|right|One of the radiator cap–themed ornaments]] From late 1928 to early 1929, modifications to the design of the dome continued. In March 1929, the press published details of an "artistic dome" that had the shape of a giant thirty-pointed star, which would be crowned by a sculpture five meters high.{{Cite news|url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1929/03/10/107095825.pdf|title=CHRYSLER BUILDING 809 FEET IN HEIGHT|last=|first=|date=March 10, 1929|work=The New York Times|access-date=November 2, 2017|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}{{dead link|date=April 2018|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}{{sfn|Bascomb|2004|p=57}} The final design of the dome included several arches and triangular windows. Lower down, the design was affected by Walter Chrysler's intention to make the building the Chrysler Corporation's headquarters, and as such, various architectural details were modeled after Chrysler automobile products, such as the hood ornaments of the [[Plymouth (automobile)|Plymouth]] (see {{section link||Designs between setbacks}}). The building's gargoyles on the 31st floor and the eagles on the 61st floor, were designed to signify flight,{{sfn|Curcio|2001|p=424}} and to exemplify the machine age of the 1920s. Even the topmost needle was built using a process similar to one Chrysler used to manufacture his cars, with precise "hand craftmanship".{{sfn|Curcio|2001|pp=423–424}} In his autobiography, Chrysler says he suggested that his building be taller than the [[Eiffel Tower]].{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books/about/Life_of_an_American_Workman.html?id=KRI-ygAACAAJ|title=Life of an American Workman|last=Chrysler|first=Walter P.|publisher=Benediction Classics|year=1950|isbn=9781849023276|location=|pages=197|language=en}}{{sfn|Landmarks Preservation Commission|1978|p=1}} Meanwhile, excavation of the {{convert|69|ft|m|adj=mid|-deep}} new building's foundation began in mid-November 1928{{sfn|Stravitz|2002|p=54}}{{sfn|Curcio|2001|p=420}} and was completed in mid-January 1929, when bedrock was reached.{{sfn|Cobb|2010|p=109}} A total of {{convert|105,000,000|lb|kg}} of rock and {{convert|36,000,000|lb|kg}} of soil was excavated for the foundation, equal to 63% of the future building's weight.{{sfn|Curcio|2001|p=420}} Construction of the building proper began on January 21, 1929.{{sfn|Cobb|2010|p=109}} The [[Carnegie Steel Company]] provided the steel beams, the first of which was installed on March 27, and by April 9, the first upright beams had been set into place.{{sfn|Curcio|2001|p=420}} The steel structure was "a few floors" high by June 1929, 35 floors high by early August,{{sfn|Curcio|2001|p=420}} and completed by September. Despite a frantic steelwork construction pace of about four floors per week, no workers died during the construction of the skyscraper's steelwork.{{Cite web|title = History of Walter P. Chrysler and the Chrysler Building|url = http://www.allpar.com/history/chrysler-building.html|access-date = February 15, 2016|publisher = Allpar|last = Massey|first = Kenneth L.}} Chrysler lauded this achievement, saying, "It is the first time that any structure in the world has reached such a height, yet the entire steel construction was accomplished without loss of life".{{cite web| title=LAUDS SAFETY RECORD | website=The New York Times | date=January 19, 1930 | url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1930/01/19/96905885.pdf | access-date=November 4, 2017}} In total, 391,881 rivets were used, and approximately 3,826,000 bricks were manually laid to create the non-loadbearing walls of the skyscraper.{{sfn|Stravitz|2002|pp=54, 158}} Walter Chrysler personally financed the construction with his income from his car company.{{cite book | last=Grigg | first=N.S. | title=Infrastructure Finance: The Business of Infrastructure for a Sustainable Future | publisher=Wiley | series=Wiley Finance | year=2010 | isbn=978-0-470-59727-9 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=v5TgZ8ckYagC | access-date=November 3, 2017 | page=52}} The Chrysler Building's height officially surpassed the Woolworth's on October 16, 1929, thereby becoming the world's tallest structure.{{cite news | title=CHRYSLER BUILDING NOW TALLEST EDIFICE; Tower Height of 808 Feet Surpasses Woolworth Structureby Sixteen Feet. | work=The New York Times | date=October 16, 1929 | url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1929/10/16/96000806.pdf | access-date=November 3, 2017}} [[Image:Chrysler Building 2005 3.jpg|thumb|left|upright|The Chrysler Building viewed through a telephoto lens from the Empire State Building]] The same year that the Chrysler Building's construction started, banker [[George L. Ohrstrom]] proposed the construction of a 47-story office building at [[40 Wall Street]] downtown. Shortly thereafter Ohrstrom modified his project to have 60 floors, but it was still below Woolworth and the 808-foot Chrysler Building project as announced in 1928. H. Craig Severance, Van Alen's former partner and the architect of 40 Wall Street, increased 40 Wall's height to {{convert|840|ft|m}} with 62 floors in April of that year. It would thus exceed the Woolworth's height by {{convert|48|ft|m}} and the Chrysler's by {{convert|32|ft|m}}. 40 Wall Street and the Chrysler Building started competing for the distinction of "[[List of tallest buildings in the world|world's tallest building]]".{{cite web|url=http://www.emporis.com/building/the-trump-building-new-york-city-ny-usa|title=Emporis Data "...a celebrated three-way race to become the tallest building in the world."|author=Emporis GmbH|publisher=Emporis.com|accessdate=September 27, 2010}}{{cite web|url=http://www.skyscraper.org/TALLEST_TOWERS/t_manco.htm|title=The Manhattan Company – Skyscraper.org; "...'race' to erect the tallest tower in the world."|publisher=Skyscraper.org|accessdate=September 27, 2010}} The [[Empire State Building]], on 34th Street and Fifth Avenue, entered the competition in 1929. The "Race into the Sky", as popular media called it at the time, was representative of the country's optimism in the 1920s, which helped fuel the building boom in major cities.{{sfn|Rasenberger|2009|pp=388–389}} The 40 Wall Street tower was revised from {{convert|840|ft|m}} to 925 feet in April 1929, which would make it the world's tallest.{{sfn|Tauranac|2014|p=130}} Severance increased the height of his project and then publicly claimed the title of the world's tallest building.Emporis Data – See source no.4 line 4; "Briefly held the world's tallest title until it was eclipsed by the spire of Chrysler Building." Construction of 40 Wall Street began in May 1929 at a frantic pace, and it was completed twelve months later. In response, Van Alen obtained permission for a {{convert|125|ft|m|adj=mid|-long}} spire{{sfn|Stravitz|2002|p=161}}{{sfn|Binder|2006|p=102}} and had it secretly constructed inside the frame of his building.{{sfn|Tauranac|2014|p=130}} The spire was delivered to the site in four different sections.{{sfn|Stravitz|2002|p=161}} On October 23, 1929, one week after surpassing the Woolworth Building's height and one day before the catastrophic [[Wall Street Crash of 1929]] started, the spire was manufactured. According to one account, "the bottom section of the spire was hoisted to the top of the building's dome and lowered into the 66th floor of the building." Then, within 90 minutes the rest of the spire's pieces were raised and riveted in sequence,{{sfn|Stravitz|2002|p=xiii, 161}} helping raise the tower's height to 1,046 feet.{{sfn|Curcio|2001|p=426}}{{sfn|Cobb|2010|p=110}} Van Alen, who witnessed the process from the street along with its engineers and Walter Chrysler,{{sfn|Curcio|2001|p=426}} compared the experience to watching a butterfly leaving its cocoon.{{sfn|Cobb|2010|p=110}} In "The Structure and Metal Work of the Chrysler Building", an article published in the October 1930 edition of ''[[Architectural Forum]]'', Van Alen explained the design and construction of the crown and needle:{{sfn|Curcio|2001|p=425}} {{quote|A high spire structure with a needle-like termination was designed to surmount the dome. This is 185 feet high and 8 feet square at its base. It was made up of four corner angles, with light angle strut and diagonal members, all told weighing 27 tons. It was manifestly impossible to assemble this structure and hoist it as a unit from the ground, and equally impossible to hoist it in sections and place them as such in their final positions. Besides, it would be more spectacular, for publicity value, to have this cloud-piercing needle appear unexpectedly.}} The steel tip brought the Chrysler Building to a height of {{convert|1046|ft|m}}, greatly exceeding 40 Wall Street's height.{{sfn|Willis|Friedman|1998|p=14}} However, contemporary news media did not write of the spire's erection, nor were there any press releases celebrating the spire's erection. Even the ''[[New York Herald Tribune]]'', which had virtually continuous coverage of the tower's construction, did not report on the spire's installation until days after the spire had been raised.{{sfn|Miller|2015|p=258}} Chrysler realized that his tower's height would exceed the Empire State Building's as well, having ordered Van Alen to change the Chrysler's original roof from a stubby [[Romanesque architecture|Romanesque]] dome to the narrow steel spire.{{sfn|Tauranac|2014|p=130}} However, the Empire State's developer [[John J. Raskob]] reviewed the plans and realized that he could add five more floors and a spire of his own to his 80-story building,{{sfn|Tauranac|2014|p=131}} and subsequently acquired the nearby plots needed to support that building's height extension.{{sfn|Bascomb|2004|p=230}}{{cite news | title=ENLARGES SITE FOR 1,000-FOOT BUILDING | work=The New York Times | date=November 19, 1929 | url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1929/11/19/107107719.pdf | access-date=October 24, 2017}} Two days later, the Empire State Building's co-developer, former Governor Al Smith, announced the updated plans for that skyscraper, with an observation deck on the 86th-floor roof at a height of {{convert|1050|ft|m}}, higher than the Chrysler's 71st-floor observation deck.{{sfn|Tauranac|2014|p=131}} === Completion === [[File:Chrysler Building Midtown Manhattan New York City 1932.jpg|thumb|right|The Chrysler Building in 1932]] In January 1930, it was announced that the Chrysler Corporation would maintain offices in the Chrysler Building during Automobile Show Week,{{Cite news|url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1930/01/05/132757162.pdf|title=DIVISION OFFICES OPENED IN NEW CHRYSLER BLDG.|last=|first=|date=1930|work=The New York Times|access-date=November 4, 2017|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}{{dead link|date=April 2018|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} and the first leases by outside tenants were announced in April 1930, before the building was officially completed.{{Cite news|url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1930/04/22/96104542.pdf|title=Universal Atlas Cement Co.
