[[Gothenburg School of Business, Economics and Law]] }} '''Leif Albert Östling''' (born 25 September 1945) is a [[Sweden|Swedish]] [[chief executive officer]] and former head of the [[Scania AB|Scania AB truck company]], owned by the German [[Volkswagen Group]].{{cite web|title=Leif Östling|url=https://www.eqtpartners.com/Organization/Others/Leif-Ostling1/|publisher=EQT|accessdate=8 April 2018}}{{cite web|title=Leif Östling|url=https://www.svensktnaringsliv.se/om_oss/ledamoter/leif-ostling-cv-englishpdf_648327.html/BINARY/Leif%20Östling%20CV%20English.pdf|publisher=Svenskt Näringsliv|accessdate=8 April 2018}}{{cite web|title=Leif Östling – resan från Luleå till industritoppen|url=http://www.nsd.se/nyheter/lulea/leif-ostling-resan-fran-lulea-till-industritoppen-nm4685664.aspx|publisher=NSD|accessdate=8 April 2018|language=Swedish}}{{cite web|title=Leif Östling|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/people/person.asp?personId=408772&ticker=VLKAY|publisher=Bloomberg|accessdate=8 April 2018}}{{cite web|title=Scania CEO Hints At Counter Bid|url=https://www.forbes.com/2006/12/06/scania-man-volkswagen-markets-equity-cx_po_1206markets12.html#6815a8bb382d|publisher=Forbes|accessdate=8 April 2018}}{{cite web|title=Scania President and CEO Leif Östling: Deregulation is creating new market conditions in Europe|url=https://www.scania.com/group/en/scania-president-and-ceo-leif-ostling-deregulation-is-creating-new-market-conditions-in-europe/|publisher=Scania|accessdate=8 April 2018}} In spring 2016, he was appointed Chairman of the [[Confederation of Swedish Enterprise]], a post he left in advance in [[November]] 2017.{{cite web|title=Svenskt Näringslivs ordförande Leif Östling avgår|url=https://www.svt.se/nyheter/inrikes/leif-ostling-avgar|publisher=SVT|accessdate=8 April 2018|language=Swedish}}{{cite web|title=Leif Östling lämnar ordförandeposten i Svenskt Näringsliv|url=https://www.svensktnaringsliv.se/kommentaren/leif-ostling-lamnar-ordforandeposten-i-svenskt-naringsliv_690105.html|publisher=Confederation of Swedish Enterprise|accessdate=8 April 2018|language=Swedish}}{{cite web|title=Head of Swedish industry group quits after tax comments|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/sweden-ostling/head-of-swedish-industry-group-quits-after-tax-comments-idUSL8N1NS1NQ|publisher=Reuters|accessdate=8 April 2018}} Östling has become known as a controversial [[political entrepreneur]] debater who makes bold statements.{{cite web|title=Östling är en frispråkig punkare iklädd kostym|url=https://www.svd.se/ostling-ar-en-frisprakig-punkare-ikladd-kostym|publisher=SvD|accessdate=8 April 2018|language=sv}} Over the years, he has separated politically from the time of youth when he belonged to the [[Swedish Social Democratic Youth League|Swedish Social Democratic Youth League, SSU]].{{cite web|title=Leif Östling – industrins frispråkige tungviktare|url=https://www.svt.se/nyheter/inrikes/leif-ostling-inustrins-frisprakige-tungviktare|publisher=SVT|accessdate=8 April 2018|language=Swedish}}{{cite web|title=Landets mest långlivade vd|url=https://www.svd.se/landets-mest-langlivade-vd|publisher=SvD Näringsliv|accessdate=8 April 2018|language=Swedish}}{{cite web|title=Det blir ingen lagstiftning om lönerna|url=http://www.ystadsallehanda.se/ledare/det-blir-ingen-lagstiftning-om-lonerna/|publisher=Ystad Allehanda|accessdate=8 April 2018|language=Swedish}} ==Education and working life== Östling was born in [[Luleå]]. After graduating with a [[Master of Engineering|Master of Engineering degree (M.Eng.)]] from the [[Chalmers University of Technology|Chalmers University of Technology, Sweden]], and a [[Bachelor of Economics|Bachelor of Economics degree (BEcon)]] from [[Gothenburg School of Business, Economics and Law]], he came in 1972 to the Scania AB division in [[Saab-Scania]], where he advanced through a variety of positions. Among other things, he was responsible for long-term planning before he was appointed head of Scania AB in the [[Netherlands]] in 1983. In 1989 he was appointed head of the Scania and in 1994 when Scania broke out of the [[Saab Scania|Saab Scania group]] and became an independent corporation, he was appointed CEO.{{cite web|title=Board of directors|url=http://www.skf.com/my/our-company/organization/corporate-governance/board-of-directors/index.html|publisher=SKF|accessdate=8 April 2018}} Östling left his post as CEO of [[Volkswagen Commercial Vehicles]] (which includes Scania AB) 2012 in connection with controversial statements that trade unions have no right of veto for a possible relocation of jobs.{{cite web|title=Leif Östling går emot fackens vetorätt|url=https://www.svd.se/leif-ostling-gar-emot-fackens-vetoratt/om/leif-ostling|publisher=SvD|accessdate=8 April 2018|language=Swedish}} Östling continued on 1 September 2012 to a position in Volkswagen AG until September 2015.{{cite web|title=Leif Östling Joins Modular Management Board|url=https://modularmanagement.com/about-us/news/|publisher=Modular Management|accessdate=8 April 2018}}{{cite web|title=Veteranen tar ut svängarna|url=https://weekend.di.se/intervjuer/veteranen-tar-ut-svangarna|publisher=Di Weekend|accessdate=8 April 2018|language=Swedish}} When Scania's former main investor [[Investor AB]] in the year of 2000 agreed that Scania AB would merge with their biggest competitor [[Volvo Trucks]], Östling opposed that merger, just as in the fall of 2006 he had opposed German [[MAN SE|MAN's]] plans to buy Scania AB. When the [[EU Commission]], referring to the [[European Union competition law]] ([[Volvo Trucks]] / [[Scania AB]] would practically have a monopoly on the truck market in the [[Nordic countries]]), stopped the merger between [[Volvo Trucks]] and [[Scania AB]],{{cite web|title=The Commission prohibits Volvo's acquisition of its main competitor Scania|url=http://europa.eu/rapid/press-release_IP-00-257_en.htm|publisher=European Commission, EU|accessdate=8 April 2018}} Östling won that battle and was able, with support from Scania's new owner [[Volkswagen]], to remain in Scania as [[CEO]]. Also, the [[MAN SE]] bid for takeover was rejected by the main shareholders,{{cite web|title=Scania shareholders reject MAN bid|url=https://www.ft.com/content/346cd5a0-467a-11db-ac52-0000779e2340|publisher=Finacial Times|accessdate=8 April 2018}}{{cite web|title=Scania board members reject VW-bid - Radio Sweden|url=http://sverigesradio.se/sida/artikel.aspx?programid=2054&artikel=5812440|publisher=Sveriges Radio|accessdate=8 April 2018|language=en}} and Östling could continue as CEO after the Annual general meeting in May 2007.{{cite web|title=Scania Minutes of the general meeting|url=https://www.scania.com/group/en/wp-content/uploads/sites/2/2015/09/Scania_AGM2007_Minutes__tcm10-164981_tcm40-50041.pdf|publisher=Scania|accessdate=8 April 2018}} ==Controversies== In 2017 Östling participated in the [[SVT]] TV program ''[[Uppdrag granskning]]'', which showed that he had placed money abroad to avoid [[Taxation in Sweden|Swedish taxation]].{{cite web|title=Svenskt Näringslivs ordförande har förmögenhet utomlands|url=https://www.svt.se/nyheter/granskning/ug/svenskt-naringslivs-ordforande-har-formogenhet-utomlands|publisher=SVT|accessdate=8 April 2018|language=Swedish}}{{cite web|title=Swedish business boss steps down in 'what do I get for my taxes' row|url=https://www.thelocal.se/20171122/swedish-business-boss-leif-ostling-steps-down-in-what-do-i-get-for-my-tax-money-row|publisher=The Local|accessdate=8 April 2018}} Also his comment in connection with that, "Here you pay 20-30 million a year, what the hell do I get for the money?", was considered inappropriate from a chairman of the [[Confederation of Swedish Enterprise]].{{cite web|title=Swedish Business Chairman Resigns Amid Paradise Papers Link|url=https://www.icij.org/investigations/paradise-papers/swedish-business-chairman-leif-ostling-resigns-amid-paradise-papers-link/|publisher=ICIJ|accessdate=8 April 2018}}{{cite web|title=Svenskt Näringslivs ordf: Vad fan får jag?|url=https://www.aftonbladet.se/nyheter/a/kqz5k/svenskt-naringslivs-ordf-vad-fan-far-jag|publisher=Aftonbladet|accessdate=8 April 2018|language=Swedish}} Östling commented later on the following discussion with "We have got a very narrow sense of corridor in Sweden if all political parties consider the political system to have unlimited taxation rights without the right of citizens to question how the money is used."{{cite web|title=Industrinestorn talar ut om hoten|url=https://weekend.di.se/intervjuer/industrinestorn-talar-ut-om-hoten|publisher=Di Weekend|accessdate=8 April 2018|language=Swedish}} Östling has said that he believes it is "genetically conditioned" that so few women enter the engineering profession. He has also expressed his belief that the threat of [[global warming]] has been exaggerated and that the phenomenon is possibly caused by natural processes, which completely opposes the consensus in the research community that the current climate change is caused by human activity.{{cite web|title=Sju klassiska Leif Östling-citat|url=https://www.svd.se/sju-klassiska-leif-ostling-citat#sida-3|publisher=SvD|accessdate=8 April 2018|language=Swedish}}{{cite web|title=Scientific consensus: Earth's climate is warming|url=https://climate.nasa.gov/scientific-consensus/|publisher=Global Climate Change, Nasa|accessdate=8 April 2018}} ==Prizes and awards== *In 2003, he was awarded an honorary doctorate at [[KTH|KTH, Stockholm]] and at [[Luleå University of Technology|Luleå University of Technology, Luleå]].{{cite web|title=List of honorary doctors at Luleå University of Technology since 1981|url=https://www.ltu.se/research/akh/Hedersdoktorer/Forteckning-over-hedersdoktorer-vid-Lulea-tekniska-universitet-sedan-1981-1.96410?l=en|publisher=Luleå University of Technology|accessdate=8 April 2018}}{{cite web|title=Honorary doctors at KTH|url=https://www.kth.se/en/om/fakta/fame/hedersdoktorer/hedersdoktorer-vid-kth-1.3974|publisher=KTH|accessdate=8 April 2018}} *In 2004, he was elected as a member of the [[Royal Swedish Academy of Engineering Sciences]].{{cite web|title=Leif Östling får IVAs Stora guldmedalj|url=https://www.iva.se/publicerat/leif-ostling-far-ivas-stora-guldmedalj/|publisher=Iva|accessdate=8 April 2018|language=Swedish}} *In 2009, he was appointed by [[Veckans Affärer]] 2008 years social capitalist.{{cite web|title=Han är årets sociala kapitalist|url=https://www.va.se/nyheter/2009/05/11/han-ar-arets-sociala-kapitalist/|publisher=Veckans Affärer|accessdate=8 April {{coord|54.5286|-1.5143|display=title|region:GB-GAT_type:landmark}} '''Lingfield Point''' is a {{convert|107|acre|km2|adj=on}} [[business park]] in [[Darlington]], [[County Durham]]<ref>[http://www.lingfieldpoint.co.uk Lingfield Point website]</ref> created on a historic industrial site previously home to Europe's largest [[wool]] manufacturing plant developed by [[Patons and Baldwins]].
==History== [[Patons and Baldwins]] built their new wool factory at Lingfield Point immediately after the [[Second World War]]. Construction started on the new factory in August 1945. The aim was to create a flagship manufacturing base for the knitting yarn company. The {{convert|107|acre|km2|adj=on}} site {{convert|2|mi|km}} to the east of the town centre was located next to the [[Stockton and Darlington Railway]] line, providing the factory with its own railway sidings.
By 1951 this wool factory was completed at a cost of £7.5m. At over {{convert|2000000|sqft|m2}} this was one of the largest wool factories in the world.<ref>[http://archive.thisisthenortheast.co.uk/2001/9/24/159098.html Great yarn of knitting giant's rise and fall]{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
==Transport== {{convert|2|mi|km}} east of [[Darlington]], Lingfield Point is located off the new Eastern Transport Corridor,<ref>[http://www.darlington.gov.uk/Living/Planning+and+Building+Control/Planning+Services/Projects+and+Schemes/EasternTransportCorridor.htm Darlington Borough Council - Eastern Transport Corridor]</ref> giving immediate access to the [[A66 road (England)|A66]] (East/West) which in turn links to J57, [[A1(M)]] South, a couple of miles from the [[A167 road (Great Britain)|A167]] which links to J59, A1(M) North.
Lingfield Point is now only minutes away from the region's extensive road network; 5 minutes from [[Darlington railway station]] – operating on the [[East Coast Main Line]] with over 30 trains per day to [[London]] and [[Edinburgh]] and {{convert|4|mi|km}} from [[Durham Tees Valley Airport]].
==Modern Transformation== 60 years later property developers [[Marchday]] transformed this manufacturing base into a large [[business park]] – one of the largest employment bases in the [[Tees Valley]] employing over 2500 people. Now owned by Clearbell, it is home to over 50 businesses and offers space from {{convert|270|sqft|m2|abbr=on}} to 150,000+ sqft. Lingfield Point has been recognised by winning a number of national and specialist awards including the British Council of Offices Recycled/Refurbished workspace award<ref>[http://www.thenorthernecho.co.uk/news/4670331.Award_for_revamped_wool_works/ The Northern Echo - Student Loans Company in the Memphis building, Lingfield Point, named best refurbished/recycled workplace in UK]</ref> in 2009 and previous winners of the [[Royal Institute of Chartered Surveyors]] (RICS) national property management award.<ref>[http://www.thenorthernecho.co.uk/archive/2004/07/13/The+North+East+Archive/6984804.Marchday_group_wins_property_management_award/ The Northern Echo - Marchday group wins property management award]</ref>
Creativity is set to continue around the 90-acre site thanks to ongoing investment. Lingfield Point hopes to become a flagship for successful regeneration in the North East – continuing to position Darlington as a great base for business.
A new £100m masterplan will see the creation of a flagship, sustainable mixed community built around the existing business community providing up to 1300 homes, sports facilities, a school, healthcare facilities and public, green open space.
Over {{convert|250000|sqft|m2|abbr=on}} of office space has been let at Lingfield Point in the last five years and more than 2500 people currently work at the business park.

{{Infobox book |name = Market Wizards |author = [[Jack D. Schwager]] | image = Market wizards.jpg | caption = Paperback 1993 | country = United States | genre = Non-fiction, [[Finance]] |language = English |publisher = [[HarperCollins]] |release_date = 1993 |pages = 480 |isbn = 0-88730-610-1 |oclc= 27967848 |followed_by = [[The New Market Wizards]] }}
'''''Market Wizards''''' is a book written by [[Jack D. Schwager]] and published in 1989 in which he interviews a wide range of [[trader (finance)|traders]] with excellent track records of profitability.
The book contains four parts covering interviews with traders in a wide range of markets. The interviews contain a mixture of facts about the trading careers of the interviewees, their philosophy, and many trading anecdotes. After each of the interviews, Schwager summarises what he believes are the key things to be learned from that particular trader. The book also contains a fifth part on the psychology of trading and two appendices on [[program trading]] and basic options theory. ''If you want to get some insights, by way of verbatim interviews, into the thought processes and trading rules.'' <ref>{{cite news| first= Stanley W| last= Angrist| publisher= The Wall Street Journal |title= Business Bookshelf: Secrets of the Super Traders | date=1989-07-24| url= https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/wsj/access/27544764.html?dids=27544764:27544764&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&date=Jul+24%2C+1989&author=By+Stanley+W.+Angrist&type=1995_1984&desc=Business+Bookshelf%3A+Secrets+of+the+Super+Traders }}</ref>
Among those profiled in this book are [[Ed Seykota]], [[Bruce Kovner]], [[Paul Tudor Jones]], [[Michael Steinhardt]], [[Van K. Tharp]] and [[Jim Rogers|James B. Rogers]].
== Traders Interviews == Schwager kicks off the series of interviews—and hence the investigation into their thought process—by talking to a man he describes as one of the pioneers of commodity trading—[[Michael Marcus (trader)|Michael Marcus]] of ''Canmarc Trading Co''. His discussion with Marcus is typical of the book as a whole. The reader effectively eavesdrops on a conversation between the two men that starts with how Marcus got into the business and continues through subjects such as the skill necessary to become a good trader.
== Follow-up books == After the success of ''Market Wizards'', Schwager in 1992 released a second book, ''[[The New Market Wizards]]'', in 2001 a third book, ''Stock Market Wizards'', and in 2012 his latest book, ''Hedge Fund Market Wizards''.

{{Infobox person | name = Mary Harriman Rumsey | image = Mary Harriman Rumsey cph.3b11336.jpg | imagesize = 150 | caption = |birth_name=Mary Harriman | birth_date = {{birth date|1881|11|17}} | birth_place = [[New York City]], U.S. | death_date = {{nowrap|{{death date and age|1934|12|18|1881|11|17}}}} | death_place = [[Washington, D.C.]], U.S. | death_cause = Horseback riding accident | resting_place = St. John's Church Cemetery, [[Arden, New York]], U.S. | resting_place_coordinates = | residence = [[Brookville, New York|Wheatley Hills, Long Island, New York]], [[Middleburg, Virginia]] | education = [[Barnard College]] | occupation = Chair of the Consumer Advisory Board, [[National Recovery Administration]] | known_for = | party = [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] | spouse = [[Charles Cary Rumsey]] | children = 3 | parents = [[E.H. Harriman]]
[[Mary Averell Harriman|Mary Averell]] | relations =[[W. Averell Harriman]] (brother)
[[E. Roland Harriman]] (brother) | boards = | awards = }} '''Mary Harriman Rumsey''' (November 17, 1881 – December 18, 1934) was the founder of The Junior League for the Promotion of Settlement Movements, later known as the Junior League of the City of New York of the [[Junior League|Association of Junior Leagues International Inc]]. Mary was the daughter of railroad magnate [[E.H. Harriman]] and sister to [[W. Averell Harriman]], former New York State Governor and United States Diplomat. In 2015 she was posthumously inducted into the [[National Women's Hall of Fame]].{{cite web|author=October 3, 2015 |url=http://www.democratandchronicle.com/story/news/2015/10/03/womens-national-hall-of-fame-seneca-falls-2015/73236506/ |title=10 women honored at Hall of Fame induction |publisher=Democratandchronicle.com |date= |accessdate=2015-10-04}} ==Early life== Mary Harriman Rumsey was born on November 17, 1881, the oldest of six children of railroad industrialist [[E.H. Harriman]] (1848–1909) and his wife, [[Mary Averell Harriman]] (1851–1932).{{cite book|last1=McHenry|first1=Robert|title=Famous American Women: A Biographical Dictionary from Colonial Times to the Present|date=1980|publisher=Dover|location=New York|isbn=0-486-24523-3|page=359}} Her siblings were Henry Neilson Harriman (1883–1888), Cornelia Harriman (1884–1966), who married [[Robert Livingston Gerry, Sr.|Robert Livingston Gerry]] (1877–1957),[https://www.nytimes.com/1908/03/04/archives/miss-harriman-bride-of-robert-l-gerry-grace-church-so-crowded-by.html New York Times article dated March 4, 1908][https://books.google.ca/books?id=tNQpAQAAMAAJ&q=Robert+livingston+Gerry+1877+1957&dq=Robert+livingston+Gerry+1877+1957&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjenp2D5cPeAhUosFQKHeD7CFIQ6AEIMDAB ''EL Harriman at Arden Farms''] Carol Averell Harriman (1889–1948), who married R. Penn Smith in 1917. After his death in 1929, she married W. Plunket Stewart, a racing stable owner in 1930,{{cite news|title=Mrs. Stewart to Sell Colts|url=http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1940/06/15/112741791.html?pageNumber=19|accessdate=19 April 2016|newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=June 15, 1940}}{{cite news|title=MRS. C.A.H. SMITH WEDS W.P. STEWART; Daughter of Mrs. E. Henry Harriman Is Married to Philadelphian at Her Country Home. WEDDING GIVES SURPRISE No Announcement Had Been Made of Betrothal of Widow of R. Penn Smith and Banker. Kin of Judge William Averell.|url=http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1930/09/18/102162616.html?pageNumber=41|accessdate=19 April 2016|newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=September 18, 1930}} [[William Averell Harriman]] (1891–1986), who in 1955 became the [[Governor of New York]] and who married Kitty Lanier Lawrence,[https://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/20/us/20mortimer.html?_r=1&ref=obituaries Kathleen Mortimer, Rich and Adventurous, Dies at 93] then [[Marie Norton Harriman|Marie Norton Whitney]] (1903–1970), and lastly to [[Pamela Harriman|Pamela Beryl Digby Churchill Hayward]] (1920–1997), and [[E. Roland Harriman|Edward Roland Noel Harriman]] (1895–1978), who married [[Gladys Fries Harriman|Gladys Fries]] (1896–1983). Mary attended [[Barnard College]], where she specialized in sociology and was a member of [[Kappa Kappa Gamma]]. == Career == === The Junior League === [[Image:Rumsey, Charles, Mary, children.jpg|thumb|Charles, Mary Averell, Mary, Charles Jr., c.1919]] Inspired by a lecture on the [[settlement movement]], Mary, along with several friends, began volunteering at the College Settlement on Rivington Street in New York City's [[Lower East Side]], a large immigrant enclave. Through her work at the College Settlement, Mary became convinced that there was more she could do to help others. Subsequently, Mary and a group of 80 debutantes established the Junior League for the Promotion of Settlement Movements in 1901, while she was still a student at Barnard College. The purpose of the Junior League would be to unite interested debutantes in joining the Settlement Movement in New York City. Realizing their lack of experience in dealing with the issues that faced people seeking help at the settlement house, Mary and League leaders brought together experts on the Settlement Movement to provide lectures and instruction to Junior League members. With better preparation came greater engagement leading to increased interest in membership by women notable in New York society; members would come to include [[Eleanor Roosevelt]], [[Dorothy Payne Whitney|Dorothy Whitney Straight]] and [[Ruth Draper]]. As word of the work of the young Junior League women in New York spread, women throughout the country and beyond formed Junior Leagues in their communities. In time, Leagues would expand their efforts beyond settlement house work to respond to the social, health and educational issues of their respective communities. In 1921, approximately 30 Leagues banded together to form the Association of Junior Leagues of America to provide support to one another. With the creation of the Association, it was Mary that insisted that although it was important for all Leagues to learn from one another and share best practices, each League was ultimately beholden to its respective community and should thus function to serve that community’s needs. As the 20th century progressed, more Junior Leagues were formed throughout the United States, Canada, Mexico and the United Kingdom. Now known as the [[Association of Junior Leagues International Inc.]] (AJLI), the organization encompasses 292 member Leagues, with over 160,000 members committed to continuing the legacy established by its founder. ===Consumer Advisory Board=== In 1933, President [[Franklin D. Roosevelt]] appointed Mary to chair the Consumer Advisory Board (CAB) of the [[National Recovery Administration]] (NRA), the first government consumer rights group. Despite her inexperience, Mary's work with farming cooperatives and belief in the power of cooperation would come to be her greatest assets. Mary would promote the formation of consumer groups across the nation and encourage these groups to report their grievances to her office. Mary Rumsey's legacy to New Deal reforms would be continued by her younger brother, [[W. Averell Harriman]]. Averell was encouraged by his older sister to leave his finance job and join her and their friends, the Roosevelts, to advance the goals of the New Deal. Averell joined the NRA, marking the beginning of his political career. == Personal life == In 1910, Mary married sculptor and polo player [[Charles Cary Rumsey]] (1879–1922), shortly after the death of her father on September 9, 1909. Rumsey had been working at Arden House, creating one of the principal fireplace surrounds, as well as other decorative sculpture. By all accounts, the two had a happy marriage.{{Cite news|url=http://portwashington-news.com/mary-harriman-rumsey-a-woman-ahead-of-her-time/|title=Mary Harriman Rumsey: A woman ahead of her time|date=2015-09-07|work=Port Washington News|access-date=2018-08-22|language=en-US}} Together they had a daughter and two sons. *Charles Harriman Rumsey (1911–2007) *Mary Averell Rumsey (b. 1913), who made her debut in 1932 at a party with over 1,100 guests.{{cite news|title=1,000 AT BALL GIVEN FOR MARY RUMSEY; Guests Invited to Come to Debutante Party on Long Island in Overalls. EVENT LIKE A BARN DANCE Decorations Are Cornstalks and Vegetables – Ham and Eggs and Apple Sauce for Supper.|url=http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1932/09/17/100851334.html?pageNumber=16|accessdate=19 April 2016|work=timesmachine.nytimes.com|publisher=''[[The New York Times]]''|date=September 17, 1932}} *Bronson Harriman Rumsey (1917–1939), who died when the plane he was riding in, along with Daniel S. Roosevelt (1917–1939) (the son of [[Hall Roosevelt]] and nephew of [[Eleanor Roosevelt]]), hit a mountain slope near [[Guadalupe Victoria, Puebla]], [[Mexico]].{{cite news|title=AIR VICTIMS' BODIES HERE; Plane Serves as Hearse for Roosevelt and Rumsey|url=http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1939/04/22/91571436.html?pageNumber=5|accessdate=19 April 2016|work=timesmachine.nytimes.com|publisher=''[[The New York Times]]''|date=April 22, 1939}} Charles was killed in a car accident in 1922.[https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9D06EED91139EF3ABC4A51DFBF668389639EDE September 22, 1922 ''New York Times'' article titled "CHARLES C. RUMSEY DIES IN AUTO CRASH ON JERICHO TURNPIKE"] Mary died in 1934 as a result of a horse riding accident which occurred while on a hunt near Middleburg, Virginia.[http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1935/01/03/93437418.html?pageNumber=46 NYTimes: Rumsey Children to Share Estate] == References == {{reflist|30em}} ===Additional sources=== * Nancy Beth Jackson, Ph. D. . ''The Junior League: 100 Years of Service''. FRP. 2001. * Janet Gordon & Diana Reische. ''The Volunteer Powerhouse''. Rutledge Press. 1982. * [http://www.ajli.org/?nd=p-who-legacy Association of Junior Leagues International: Legacy] * [http://www.ajli.org/?nd=p-who-legacy-famous-list Association of Junior Leagues International: Notable Members] * [https://barnardarchives.wordpress.com/2011/01/01/mary-harriman-rumsey-05/ Barnard Archives and Special Collections: Mary Harriman Rumsey 1905]. ==External links== *{{Commonscat-inline}} {{National Women's Hall of Fame}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Rumsey, Mary Harriman}} [[Category:1881 births]] [[Category:1934 deaths]] [[Category:Deaths by horse-riding accident]] [[Category:Barnard College alumni]] [[Category:Philanthropists from New York (state)]] [[Category:Consumer rights activists]] [[Category:New York (state) Democrats]] [[Category:Harriman family]] [[Category:Accidental deaths in Washington, D.C.]] [[Category:American women philanthropists]] [[Category:Activists from New York City]] [[Category:American women activists]] [[Category:People from Brookville, New York]] [[Category:People from Middleburg, Virginia]]

{{Infobox Congressman | name = Peter Frelinghuysen Jr. | image name =Frelinghuysen, PHB.png | caption = | state = [[New Jersey]] | district = [[New Jersey's 5th congressional district|5th]] | term_start = January 3, 1953 | term_end = January 3, 1975 | preceded = [[Charles Aubrey Eaton]] | succeeded = [[Millicent Fenwick]] |birth_name=Peter Hood Ballantine Frelinghuysen | birth_date = {{birth date|1916|1|17}} | birth_place = [[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]] | death_date = {{death date and age|2011|5|23|1916|1|17}} | death_place = [[Harding Township, New Jersey]] | party = [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] | alma_mater=[[Princeton University]]
[[Yale Law School]] | spouse = Beatrice Sterling Procter | children =[[Rodney P. Frelinghuysen]] }} '''Peter Hood Ballantine Frelinghuysen II''' (January 17, 1916 – May 23, 2011) was an American politician. He represented [[New Jersey]]'s [[New Jersey's 5th congressional district|fifth congressional district]] in the [[United States House of Representatives]] as a [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] from 1953 to 1975.{{cite web |url=http://bioguide.congress.gov/scripts/biodisplay.pl?index=F000371 |title=Peter Hood Ballantine Frelinghuysen |accessdate=2011-05-24 |quote= |publisher=[[Biographical Directory of the United States Congress]] }} ==Early years== Peter Frelinghuysen came from a long line of New Jersey politicians dating back to the early years of the United States, including four United States senators and two House members. He was the grandson of [[George Griswold Frelinghuysen]], great-grandson of [[Frederick T. Frelinghuysen]], the great-great-nephew of [[Theodore Frelinghuysen]], and the great-great-great-grandson of [[Frederick Frelinghuysen (1753–1804)|Frederick Frelinghuysen]]. He was also a great-great-grandson of [[Ballantine Brewery]] founder [[Peter Ballantine]]. Born on January 17, 1916, in [[New York City]] to Peter H.B. Frelinghuysen Sr. and the former [[Henry Osborne Havemeyer#Personal and family life|Adaline Havemeyer]], Frelinghuysen's father was a banker who descended from 18th century Dutch settlers in [[Somerset County, New Jersey|Somerset County]].{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/05/24/nyregion/peter-frelinghuysen-jr-95-longtime-nj-congressman-dies.html?ref=deathsobituaries|title=Peter Frelinghuysen Jr., 95, Former Congressman, Dies|author=Joseph P. Fried|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=May 23, 2011|accessdate=May 27, 2011}}{{efn|Frelinghuysen Sr., a Princeton graduate, was a classmate at Columbia Law School of President Franklin D. Roosevelt, who served as an usher at his 1902 wedding to Adaline Havemeyer. Frelinghuysen Sr. devoted himself to cattle breeding in addition to banking.{{cite book|last=Rae|first=John W.|title=Mansions of Morris County |year=1999 |publisher=Arcadia |isbn=978-0-7385-0064-5 |page=75 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jLGDcu-PsrkC&pg=PA75&}}}} His siblings included his twin brother Henry O.H. Frelinghuysen, a philanthropist and civic leader,{{cite news|title=H. Frelinghuysen, A Philanthropist, 78 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/04/01/obituaries/h-frelinghuysen-a-philanthropist-78.html|accessdate=June 4, 2013 |newspaper=New York Times|date=April 1, 1994}} George G. Frelinghuysen, and Frederica Frelinghuysen Emert.{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=H. Frelinghuysen, A Philanthropist, 78 |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9E0DE3D9123FF932A35757C0A962958260|publisher=[[New York Times]] |date=April 1, 1994 |accessdate=July 1, 2008 }} He attended [[St. Mark's School (Massachusetts)|St. Mark's School]] in [[Southborough, Massachusetts]], and graduated from [[Princeton University]] in 1938 and [[Yale Law School]] in 1941. ==Career== After practicing law in New York City, he served in the [[Office of Naval Intelligence]] from September 1942 to December 1945 obtaining the rank of lieutenant. He then studied at [[Columbia University]], 1946–1947. He served as staff of the Foreign Affairs Task Force of the [[Hoover Commission]] in 1948 before returning to the private sector. He served as director of Howard Savings Bank in [[Livingston, New Jersey]].{{efn|Howard Savings was founded as Howard Savings Institution in Newark in 1857.{{cite book|last=Tuttle|first=Brad R.|title=How Newark Became Newark: The Rise, Fall, and Rebirth of an American City|year=2009|publisher=Rutgers University Press|isbn=978-0813544908|page=36 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=z5oWapZqV5kC&pg=PA36&}} It was purchased by First Fidelity Bancorporation of Newark in 1992.{{cite news|last=Quint|first=Michael|title=Two Banks Shut and Sold, In Newark and New Haven |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1992/10/03/business/two-banks-shut-and-sold-in-newark-and-new-haven.html|accessdate=June 4, 2013 |newspaper=New York Times|date=October 3, 1992}}}} In 1952, he was elected to the House of Representatives from [[New Jersey's 5th congressional district]] and served there until his retirement from politics in 1975.{{cite news |author=Walter H. Waggoner|title=Frelinghuysen Favored Over Vigorous Democratic Foe in Jersey's Fifth District |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1970/10/06/archives/frelinghuysen-favored-over-vigorous-democratic-foe-in-jerseys-fifth.html |newspaper=[[New York Times]] |date=October 6, 1970 |accessdate=May 23, 2011 }} As a moderate Republican, he supported the [[Civil Rights Act of 1964]], but not the Johnson administration's [[war on poverty]] programs. [[File:Longines Chronicles with Peter Frelinghuysen 1954 ARC-96008.ogv|thumb|right|1954 interview]] In December 1959, when the [[Port Authority of New York and New Jersey|Port of New York Authority]]'s plans to develop a tract of woodlands and marsh near his estate in Morris County as an international airport serving the New York City region were exposed, Frelinghuysen participated in the opposition by the Jersey Jetport Site Association that was composed of local residents and conservationists,{{cite news|last=Dean|first=Clarence|title=Plan for Airport Argued in New Jersey |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1960/01/14/99471228.pdf |accessdate=June 5, 2013 |newspaper=New York Times|date=January 14, 1960}}{{cite news|last=Honig|first=Milton|title=Jetport Enemies Say They've Won|url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1961/12/17/97630846.pdf|accessdate=June 5, 2013|newspaper=New York Times|date=December 17, 1961}}{{cite book|last=Doig|first=Jameson W.|title=Empire on the Hudson: Entrepreneurial Vision and Political Power at the Port of New York Authority|year=2001|publisher=Columbia University Press|pages=385–6|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Ets_wW6cnRYC&pg=PA385&}} which raised funds to purchase almost 3,000 acres of the targeted site and donated it to the federal government, to be preserved forever as park lands. With the defeat of the airport development initiative, that parcel became the initial portion of the [[Great Swamp National Wildlife Refuge]], established by federal statute on November 3, 1960, in the middle of the development controversy. In the 1960s, extortionists targeted Frelinghuysen for blackmail, arranging for him to have a sexual encounter with an underage male and then, posing as police officers, threatening him with public exposure. Frelinghuysen paid them $50,000. He later cooperated with the FBI's investigation of the [[The Chickens and the Bulls|extortionist ring]], but the [[United States Department of Justice|Justice Department]] notified the leadership of the House of Representatives and Frelinghuysen was forced off the [[United States House Committee on Armed Services|Armed Services Committee]].{{cite news|last=McGowan |first=William |title=The Chickens and the Bulls|url=http://www.slate.com/articles/life/history/2012/07/the_chickens_and_the_bulls_the_rise_and_incredible_fall_of_a_vicious_extortion_ring_that_preyed_on_prominent_gay_men_in_the_1960s_.html |accessdate=June 4, 2013|newspaper=Slate.com|date=July 11, 2012}} In January 1965, he was House Minority Leader [[Gerald Ford]]'s choice for Minority Whip, but lost on a secret ballot of the Republican caucus by a vote of 70 to 59 to the incumbent [[Leslie C. Arends|Les Arends]], who had held the post since 1943.{{cite news|last=Brown|first=Emma|title=Peter H.B. Frelinghuysen Jr., former N.J. congressman, dies at 95|url=https://articles.washingtonpost.com/2011-05-24/local/35263829_1_frederick-frelinghuysen-republican-leadership-morris-county|archive-url=https://archive.is/20130630142807/http://articles.washingtonpost.com/2011-05-24/local/35263829_1_frederick-frelinghuysen-republican-leadership-morris-county|dead-url=yes|archive-date=June 30, 2013|accessdate=June 5, 2013|newspaper=Washington Post|date=May 24, 2011}}{{cite news|last=Morris|first=John D. |title=Arends Retained; Ford Rebuffed|url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1965/01/15/101521639.pdf |accessdate=June 5, 2013|newspaper=New York Times|date=January 15, 1965}} After leaving Congress, Frelinghuysen served on the boards of several nonprofit institutions, including the [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]] and the [[New York Botanical Garden]]. ==Personal life== He married the former Beatrice Sterling Procter, in Stockbridge, Massachusetts, on September 7, 1940.{{cite news|title=Beatrice S. Procter Married to P.H.B. Frelinghuysen Jr.|url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1940/09/08/93990717.pdf |accessdate=June 4, 2013|newspaper=New York Times|date=September 8, 1940}} She was a descendent of the founder of [[Procter & Gamble]]. Their children include Peter Frelinghuysen II, a lawyer, and [[Rodney P. Frelinghuysen]], a congressman.{{cite news |author= |coauthors= |title=Miss Beattie, Mr. Frelinghuysen |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/07/17/style/weddings-miss-beattie-mr-frelinghuysen.html?src=pm |newspaper=[[New York Times]] |date=July 17, 1994 |accessdate=May 23, 2011 }} His wife died in 1996. He died on May 23, 2011, at his home in [[Harding Township, New Jersey]]. ==Notes== {{Notelist}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== * {{Congbio|F000371|findagrave=70294394|retrieved=June 6, 2013}} *[http://arks.princeton.edu/ark:/88435/4j03cz67r Peter H.B. Frelinghuysen Papers at the Seeley G. Mudd Manuscript Library, Princeton University] * {{Internet Archive film clip|id=gov.archives.arc.96008|description="Longines Chronoscope with Peter Freylinghuysen (SIC)"}} {{s-start}} {{s-par|us-hs}} {{succession box | before=[[Charles Aubrey Eaton]] | title=[[US Congressional Delegations from New Jersey|U.S. House of Representatives
5th District of New Jersey]] | years=1953–1975 | after=[[Millicent Fenwick]]}} {{s-end}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Frelinghuysen, Peter Jr.}} [[Category:1916 births]] [[Category:2011 deaths]] [[Category:People from Harding Township, New Jersey]] [[Category:Princeton University alumni]] [[Category:Yale Law School alumni]] [[Category:Frelinghuysen family|Peter]] [[Category:Havemeyer family]] [[Category:Members of the United States House of Representatives from New Jersey]] [[Category:New Jersey Republicans]] [[Category:American people of Dutch descent]] [[Category:St. Mark's School (Massachusetts) alumni]] [[Category:United States Navy officers]] [[Category:People of the Office of Naval Intelligence]] [[Category:Republican Party members of the United States House of Representatives]] [[Category:Articles containing video clips]] [[Category:20th-century American politicians]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2013}} {{Infobox person | name = Richard Chandler | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_name = Richard Fred Chandler | birth_date = {{birth based on age as of date |59|2018|02|12}} | birth_place = New Zealand | residence = [[Singapore]] | nationality = New Zealand | known_for = | education = | occupation = Investor | home_town = | title = | networth = US$3.2 billion (August 2018){{cite web|title=Forbes profile: Richard Chandler|url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/richard-chandler/#7457f1f21d4d|website=Forbes|accessdate=22 August 2018}} | boards = | spouse = Married | children = | website = | parents = Robert Chandler
[[Ana Tzarev]] | relatives = [[Christopher Chandler (businessman)|Christopher Chandler]] (brother) }} '''Richard Fred Chandler''' (born 1958/59) is a New Zealand-born[http://www.chandlergroup.com/publications/S_Sov.pdf The Secrets of Sovereign], ''[[Institutional Investor (magazine)|Institutional Investor]]'', March 2006. [[billionaire]] businessman. He is chairman of the Clermont Group, a Singapore-based business group that invests in public and private companies across a range of industries, including energy, financial services, consumer, and healthcare.[http://www.chandlergroup.com/chandler-corporation Chandler Corporation], [http://www.chandlergroup.com "ChandlerGroup.com"], July 2013.http://www.clermont.com/home Chandler "has a reputation for buying struggling companies and successfully rebuilding them," according to Australian Broadcasting Corporation News.[http://www.abc.net.au/news/2012-02-08/gunns-saviour-a-reclusive-billionaire/3819468 Gunns Saviour a Reclusive Billionaire], ''[[ABC News (Australia)|ABC News]]'', February 2012. He also has been known to "take a business approach to philanthropy."[https://www.forbes.com/global/2008/0310/049.html 48 Asian Altruists], ''[[Forbes]]'', February 2008. ==Early life== Born in New Zealand, Chandler is the son of [[beekeeper]]s Robert and Marija Chandler, who launched and operated Chandler House, a department store in [[Hamilton, New Zealand]].{{cite web |url=http://www.legatum.com/about-us/our-story/ |title=Our story |publisher=Legatum |access-date=13 February 2018}} ==Career== Chandler was formerly CEO of the Sovereign group of companies, in partnership with his brother, [[Christopher Chandler (businessman)|Christopher Chandler]]. Between 1986 and 2006, Sovereign invested in companies and governments in Asia, Africa, Latin America and Eastern Europe, and in industries including telecommunications, electric utilities, steel, oil and gas, banking and oil refining.[https://www.forbes.com/lists/2009/10/billionaires-2009-richest-people_Richard-Chandler_UX5G.html "The World's Billionaires (2009)"], ''[[Forbes]]'', November 2009. The brothers split their assets in 2007 with Richard Chandler creating Orient Global and Christopher Chandler starting [[Legatum|Legatum Capital]].{{cite news |url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/business/news/article.cfm?c_id=3&objectid=10405311 |title=Chandler Brothers split up interests |author=McSheehy, Will |date=11 October 2006 |agency=[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]] |work=[[The New Zealand Herald]] |accessdate=5 November 2011}} Richard's investment style has been described as deep [[value investing]], primarily in global emerging markets and especially in distress situations. Orient Global changed its name to Richard Chandler Corporation in April 2010 before becoming the Chandler Corporation in 2013, and the Clermont Group in 2016. The company "is a long-term value investor that believes well-governed companies play a fundamental role in creating national prosperity," according to its website. Richard Chandler's business ventures have been tinged with themes of contrarian investment, corporate governance and social responsibility, especially by investing in and managing companies with national socio-economic implications.[http://www.santangelsreview.com/2011/07/24/richard-chandler-sino-forest-and-how-to-turn-10-million-into-5-billion "Richard Chandler, Sino-Forest, and how $10 million turned into $5 billion"],''[http://www.santangelsreview.com "Santangels Review"]'', July 2011. He once told [[Institutional Investor (magazine)|Institutional Investor]], "We do have altruistic motives that some investors who are looking for a path of least resistance find hard to understand, but we don’t want to be defined by our corporate governance battles. We are value investors with a sense of responsibility, not activists." The Chandler brothers were involved in a highly publicized incident in 2005. Sovereign sold its investment in South Korea's SK Corp., at the time South Korea's third-largest oil conglomerate, after the board refused to oust chairman and CEO Chey Tae Won. Chey had been convicted of accounting fraud for illegally trading stocks. Sovereign had invested in the company just after Chey's arrest, hoping to turn it around. Richard Chandler and his brother tried twice unsuccessfully to remove Chey and ultimately pulled out for ethical reasons. By that point they had improved the company and profited US$728 million. In 2007 Richard Chandler launched a US$100 million education initiative in the developing world with the focus to build low-cost private education opportunities in India. Furthermore, he invested in a global chain of international [[K-12]] schools called [[Nobel Education Network]].{{cite web|title=Open Corporate|url=https://opencorporates.com/companies/gb/04887133|website=opencorporates.com|publisher=Chrinon Ltd|accessdate=10 October 2014}} Multiple media outlets reported in 2012 that Chandler considered investing in the Tasmanian logging company, [[Gunns]], but ultimately decided not to.[http://www.smh.com.au/business/gunns-blames-greens-for-billionaire-blow-20120309-1uo9m.html Gunns blames Greens for billionaire blow], ''[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]'', March 2012. [[Yahoo finance|Yahoo Finance]] reported in June 2013 that Chandler's company acquired an 80% stake in Hoan My Medical Corporation, Vietnam's largest private hospital group. According to the article's author, the transaction "complements the healthcare businesses the Chandler Corporation owns and operates in Indonesia and the Philippines, positioning it to become a leading private healthcare provider in Asia."[https://finance.yahoo.com/news/chandler-corporation-acquires-80-shareholding-140200879.html Chandler Corporation Acquires an 80% Shareholding in Vietnam's Hoan My Medical Corporation], ''[[Yahoo finance|Yahoo Finance]]'', June 2013. == Philanthropy == In November 2017, Richard Chandler was invited to be a core partner in Co-Impact, a new global model for collaborative philanthropy and social change at scale. Other core partners include [[Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation|Bill and Melinda Gates]], [[Jeffrey Skoll|Jeff Skol]]l, [[Romesh Wadhwani|Romesh]] and Kathy Wadhwani, and [[Rockefeller Foundation|The Rockefeller Foundation]].{{Cite news|url=http://www.co-impact.io/2017/11/15/leading-philanthropists-announce-co-impact-global-collaborative-systems-change-500-million-planned-initial-funding/|title=Leading Philanthropists Announce Co-Impact, A Global Collaborative for Systems Change, with US $500 Million in Planned Initial Funding - Co-Impact|date=2017-11-15|work=Co-Impact|access-date=2018-04-06|language=en-US}} ==Personal life== Chandler is married to Kady Leyau, a business woman, former model, actress, and VJ at Taiwan MTV.{{cite web|url=https://www.businesstimes.com.sg/real-estate/belmont-rd-gcb-fetches-s338m-or-s2243-psf|title=Belmont Rd GCB fetches S$33.8m or S$2,243 psf|author=|date=|website=businesstimes.com.sg|accessdate=27 August 2018}}{{cite web|url=https://www.edgeprop.sg/property-news/luxury-bungalows-belmont-road-sentosa-cove-sold-more-33-million|title=Luxury bungalows at Belmont Road, Sentosa Cove sold for more than $33 million|author=|date=|website=edgeprop.sg|accessdate=27 August 2018}} == References == == External links == * [http://www.milfordasset.com/oz-deal-brings-chandler-closer-to-home/ Chandler Family History] * http://www.clermont.com/home {{DEFAULTSORT:Chandler, Richard (Businessman)}} [[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:New Zealand businesspeople]] [[Category:New Zealand expatriates in Monaco]] [[Category:New Zealand investors]] [[Category:New Zealand billionaires]] [[Category:1950s births]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2012}} {{Use South African English|date=November 2012}} '''Richard John Pelwana Maponya''', [[Order of the Baobab|GCOB]],<ref name="gcob">[http://www.thepresidency.gov.za/orders_list.asp?show=343 The Presidency - Republic of South Africa - Grand Counsellor of The Order of the Baobab in Gold]</ref> (born in [[Tzaneen]],[[Transvaal Province|Transvaal]] on 24 December 1926<ref name="gcob" />) is a [[South Africa]]n entrepreneur and [[property developer]] best known for building a business empire despite the restrictions of [[apartheid]] and his determination to see the [[Soweto]] township develop [[economics|economically]].
==Early career== Born in Thlabine, near Lenyenye- about 20km west of Tzaneen, Maponya, at the age of 24,<ref name="age">zwtetete [https://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20081004/ap_on_re_af/af_south_africa_soweto_entrepreneur Up from apartheid, Soweto millionaire a role model - AP]</ref> then a teacher, took a job as a stock taker at a clothing maker and subsequently won a promotion for both himself and his white manager. In gratitude, the manager sold Maponya soiled clothing and offcuts, which he resold in Soweto. With the capital acquired he attempted to open a clothing retailer in Soweto, but was blocked by the government's refusal to grant him a licence – despite the intervention by the law firm created by [[Oliver Tambo]] and [[Nelson Mandela]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,1657164,00.html|title=Retail Renegade: Richard Maponya|publisher=Time magazine|accessdate=7 July 2008 | date=29 August 2007}}</ref>
Instead, in the early 1950s, Maponya and his wife Marina (a cousin of Nelson Mandela) established the [[Dube Hygienic Dairy]], which employed a fleet of boys on bicycles to deliver milk to customers in Soweto who had no access to electricity or refrigeration.<ref name="ReferenceA">Soweto Rising, [[Maverick (magazine)|Maverick magazine]], volume 2, issue 2</ref> By the 1970s the retail empire had grown to include several general stores, car dealerships and filling stations.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,1657164-2,00.html|title=Retail Renegade: Richard Maponya|publisher=Time magazine|accessdate=7 July 2008 | date=29 August 2007}}</ref>
==Political activity== During the 1960s and 1970s Maponya was a member of the [[South Africa under apartheid|Urban Bantu Council]]. He resigned in 1977, shortly after youth affiliated with the [[African National Congress]] (ANC) requested that he do so, and shortly before the council offices were burnt to the ground.<ref name="ReferenceA"/>
In the 1960s he was a founding member and the first president of the [[National African Federated Chamber of Commerce]] (Nafcoc) and likewise the founder and chairman of the [[African Chamber of Commerce]].
But some consider his boldest political move to have been his choice of horse-racing colors. As the first black person to be granted such colors in South Africa, Maponya chose green, gold and black, the colors of the ANC.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mg.co.za/article/2005-08-17-i-will-die-with-my-boots-on|title='I will die with my boots on'|publisher=Mail & Guardian|accessdate=7 July 2008}}</ref>
==Maponya Mall== On 27 September 2007 Richard Maponya opened the [[Maponya Mall]] in Soweto. it holds more than 200 stores and a cinema complex.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sabcnews.com/south_africa/general/0,2172,156535,00.html|title=Mandela officially opens new Soweto mall|publisher=SABC|accessdate=7 July 2008}}</ref>
Maponya acquired the land where the mall is situated in 1979, at first as a 100-year lease. In 1994, after several attempts, he acquired it outright. Various attempts to finance construction failed until Maponya's holding company entered into a joint venture with [[Zenprop Property Holdings]].
==Awards== [[Order of the Baobab|Grand Counselor of the Baobab]], April 2007<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.info.gov.za/aboutgovt/orders/recipients/2007apr.htm|title=National Orders awards 24 April 2007|publisher=SA Government Communication and Information Service|accessdate=7 July 2008}}</ref>
==See also== [[Soweto]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2016}} {{Infobox person | name = Sandeep Sander | image = 2015-04-05_Sandeep_Sander_photo_for_Wikipedia.png | alt = | caption = | birth_name = <!-- only use if different from name --> | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1957|8|18|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Copenhagen]], Denmark | death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|df=yes|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} or {{Death-date and age|df=yes|death date†|birth date†}} --> | death_place = | nationality = Danish, Indian | other_names = | occupation = CEO, chairman, sailor | years_active = | known_for = | notable_works = }}
'''Sandeep Sander''' (born 18 August 1957 in [[Copenhagen]]) is the CEO of [[SanderMap]] GmbH Switzerland. He is also chairman of advisory boards, and advisor to chairmen and CEOs of global corporations. He is a speaker at business schools and conferences<ref>{{cite web|title=Sandeep Sander Profile|url=http://www.connect6.com/Sandeep-Sander/p/124003018184190039207017143061196068165056056125070123085038189101051125149193159145171010010200|website=Connect 6|accessdate=14 April 2015}}</ref> about [[talent management]] and [[Human Asset Management|human asset management]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Networking, Mobility and Competences can get you the best jobs!|url=https://e-campus.dk/portal/pls/portal/ec_message_board.content_api.showfile?fid=21480586.PDF|website=e-campus.dk|accessdate=14 April 2015}}</ref>
==Early life== Sandeep Sander, born to an Indian father, Satinath Mukherji (a scientist who started his career at Novo, now [[Novo Nordisk|Novo-Nordisk]]) and a Danish mother, Ida Wolff Sander, lived his childhood in [[Jyllinge]], Denmark, except for two years in [[Malmö]], Sweden. In Jyllinge, he got into sailing when he was 10 years old.
After high school Sander attended [[Copenhagen Business School]], studying part-time and working full-time at Butik Ole, started by Ole Hendriksen, who was also a volunteer leader in Jyllinge Sailing Club. Sander graduated as B.Com. in Management Accounting in 1980 and B.com in Financial Management in 1981.
After working in some mid-sized organizations he started his first company in 1983 (at age 25) and sold it in 1985. That year he started his MBA one-year program at [[INSEAD]] in Fontainebleau, France.<ref>{{cite web|title=Sejlsport og succes|url=http://borsen.dk/nyheder/avisen/artikel/12/3024717/artikel.html?hl=U2FuZGVlcCBTYW5kZXI|website=Borsen.dk|accessdate=26 April 2015}}</ref>
==Career==
In 1983 Sander started Sander Inter Trade, which soon became SIT Water Systems. The company was sold in 1985. Soon, in parallel with applying for the MBA program at INSEAD, he started Green Food with a business friend. After living in France for two years and finishing the INSEAD MBA, he was hired by Skandinavisk Holding and worked on acquisitions and strategy development until 1988.
In 1989 Green Food was sold and Sander & Company started working with another consulting company and servicing international corporations like Egmont. Sander & Company later became SanderMap.
In partnership with a global IT firm,<ref>{{cite web|title=Software-gigant håndplukker dansk partner|url=http://borsen.dk/nyheder/avisen/artikel/12/3024717/artikel.html?hl=U2FuZGVlcCBTYW5kZXI|website=Borsen.dk|accessdate=14 April 2015}}</ref> SanderMap gained clients including [[Credit Suisse]] and [[Canon Inc.|Canon]]. In 1999 the headquarters was moved to [[Cobham, Kent|Cobham]], near London. In 2002 SanderMap was sold and in 2003 Sander moved back to Denmark.
Sander was a contributor to the Danish version of ''Global Strategy'', George Yip, Systime in 1994 as well as a contributor to the book ''Brand Leadership: Building Assets in an Information Economy''.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Joachimsthaler|first1=Dasvid A. Aaker, Erich|title=Brand leadership|date=2011|publisher=Free Press|location=New York|isbn=1439172919}}</ref>
In February 2015 he was invited to join the "Innovation for Jobs" Summit (i4J) at Google's headquarters to discuss future solutions. His contributions were included in the films ''What is the Future of meaningful work'' and ''What is [[Employability]]?''<ref>{{cite web|title=You Won't Be Automated: Innovation for Jobs|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=y-DD3ODAMjs|website=Youtube|accessdate=21 April 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=What is Employability?|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8kXdgrjHpyM|website=Youtube|accessdate=14 April 2015}}</ref>
Sander has been chairman of a number of corporations, including Crowne Plaza Copenhagen Towers hotel and Copenhagen Towers business centre, a real estate company. Crowne Plaza became the first CO2 neutral hotel building in Northern Europe, just before COP15, a global climate conference in Copenhagen. In 2013 Sander became CEO of SanderMap Pte. Ltd. Singapore. In September 2013 he was an expert speaker on competence development and human asset management at the National Conference on Skill Development, Gujarat, India.<ref>{{cite web|title=Sandeep Sander Profile|url=https://sg.linkedin.com/in/sandeepsander|website=Linkedin|accessdate=21 April 2015}}</ref>
In 2016 he became CEO of SanderMap GmbH Switzerland.
In 2018 Sander contributed to defining risk transformation -<ref>https://sandermap.com</ref> how to mitigate risk and develop competitive advantages.
He also is a researcher in [[Human Asset Management|human asset management]].
==Personal life==
Sander was married to Gitte on 4 June 1988. They have three children; Jacob Sander (born 1992), David Mukherji Sander (born 1994) and Sarah Maria Sander (born 1996).
Sailing has always been an important part of life for Sander, first as a sailor at international level, then as a father to three young sailors and volunteer. He has been a board member of [[Royal Danish Yacht Club]], responsible for the commercial activities and Chairman for Optimist Sailing Team Denmark, the Danish organization for the world's largest boat class. He is now chairman of Sailing Denmark, a charitable organization raising funds for youth sailing.<ref>{{cite web|title=Ynglinge-sejlere: Grundløse anklager mod Jørgen Ring og Sailing Denmark|url=http://minbaad.dk/nyhed/?tx_ttnews%5Btt_news%5D=618602&cHash=91615131e9989aa1bb87bf8c967accf2|website=Minbaad.dk|accessdate=14 April 2015}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}

{{Infobox person | name = Scott Gilmore | other_names = | image = | image_size = | caption = Scott Gilmore, the founder of Building Markets speaking on BBC's Doha Debates | birth_date = | birth_place = [[Flin Flon]], Canada | death_date = | death_place = | alma mater = [[University of Alberta]], [[London School of Economics]] | known_for = Founding Building Markets | occupation = [[Social Entrepreneur]], Writer, [[Diplomat]] |party = [[Conservative Party of Canada|Conservative]] | spouse = [[Catherine McKenna]]<ref name="Catherine McKenna">{{cite web | url=http://www.canada.com/story.html?id=e3d5dc04-83b2-4c25-add7-bbfe2a59eeeb | title=Small NGO, big results | publisher=[[Ottawa Citizen]] | date=7 January 2015 | accessdate=31 October 2015 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160324222748/http://www.canada.com/story.html?id=e3d5dc04-83b2-4c25-add7-bbfe2a59eeeb | archivedate=24 March 2016 | df= }}</ref> | parents = | children = }}
'''Scott Gilmore''' is a Canadian [[social entrepreneur]], former diplomat, and writer who is known for founding the charity [[Peace Dividend Trust|Building Markets]] and as an advocate for reform in the international development and charity sectors.<ref name="Transformational Cdn" />
==Early life and education== Gilmore was born in northern [[Manitoba]], the son of hockey player [[Tom Gilmore (ice hockey)|Tom Gilmore]] and Collette Gilmore. He is the brother of actor [[Patrick Gilmore (actor)|Patrick Gilmore]]. Gilmore grew up in [[Edmonton, Alberta]] where he obtained a Bachelor of Commerce degree at the [[University of Alberta]].<ref name=Pilger>{{cite web|last1=Pilger|first1=Rick|title=Putting Money Where It Matters Most|url=http://newtrail.ualberta.ca/featurestories/scottgilmore|website=http://ualberta.ca|accessdate=26 October 2014}}</ref> He later graduated with a master's degree from the [[London School of Economics]].<ref name="Transformational Cdn" />
==Career==
Gilmore was a Canadian diplomat who began his career in Jakarta. From that post he covered the East Timor conflict and later joined the [[United Nations]] peacekeeping mission [[UNTAET]] under [[Sergio de Mello]]. In that role he became disillusioned with ineffective donor efforts to fight poverty. Based on this experience he quit his job as a diplomat in 2004 to launch the charity [[Peace Dividend Trust|Building Markets]].<ref name="This Mag">{{cite news|last1=Scott|first1=Graham F.|title=Interview with Peace Dividend Trust's Scott Gilmore|url=http://this.org/blog/2010/01/19/interview-scott-gilmore/|accessdate=26 October 2014|agency=This Magazine|date=January 19, 2010}}</ref> and focus on entrepreneurship instead of aid as a sustainable poverty solution.<ref name=Forbes>{{cite news|last1=Carlyle|first1=Erin|title=Building Markets: Meet The Start-Up Bringing Investors To The Fastest-Growing Economies in the World|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/erincarlyle/2013/11/17/building-markets-meet-the-start-up-bringing-investors-to-the-fastest-growing-economies-in-the-world/|accessdate=26 October 2014|publisher=Forbes Magazine|date=2013-11-17}}</ref>
In 2006 Gilmore led a [[World Bank]] study to trace spending in peacekeeping missions that revealed only 5% of donor money entered the local economies. Based on those findings Gilmore launched a project in Afghanistan to channel international spending through local small businesses. This approach was successful and expanded to other countries.<ref name="Transformational Cdn" /> Building Market's "buy local" policy was officially adopted by [[NATO]], the United States government, and the [[United Nations]].<ref name=Pilger /><ref>{{cite web|title=NATO Afghan First Policy|url=http://www.nato.int/cps/en/natohq/official_texts_62851.htm|website=NATO|accessdate=27 October 2014}}</ref> In 2013 Gilmore was appointed to by the External Advisory Group overseeing the merger of the [[Department of Foreign Affairs and International Trade (Canada)|Canadian Department of Foreign Affairs and International Trade]] with the [[Canadian International Development Agency]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Blanchfield|first1=Mike|title=Paradis defends mining exec on advisory panel on international aid|url=http://globalnews.ca/news/935875/paradis-defends-mining-exec-on-advisory-panel-on-international-aid/|accessdate=27 October 2014|publisher=Global News|date=October 30, 2013}}</ref> He had previously been supportive of the merger.<ref name="CIDA Merger">{{cite news|last1=Berthiaume|first1=Lee|title=CIDA merger meets with controversy|url=http://www2.canada.com/vancouversun/news/archives/story.html?id=debacf11-51f7-45c8-be14-44eddda98579|accessdate=27 October 2014|publisher=Vancouver Sun|date=March 23, 2013}}</ref>
In 2014 Gilmore began writing a weekly column for the Canadian week national newsmagazine ''[[Maclean's]]''.<ref name=Macleans>{{cite web|title=Maclean's Magazine|url=http://www.macleans.ca/author/scottgilmore/|accessdate=26 October 2014}}</ref>
==Awards and honours== Gilmore was named a "[[25 Transformational Canadians|Transformational Canadian]]" by ''[[The Globe and Mail]]''<ref name="Transformational Cdn">{{cite news|last1=Rockel|first1=Nick|title=Scott Gilmore makes peace missions more effective|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/report-on-business/scott-gilmore-makes-peace-missions-more-effective/article1319533/|accessdate=26 October 2014|agency=The Globe and Mail|date=Dec 14, 2010}}</ref> and a [[Young Global Leader]]s by the [[World Economic Forum]]. In 2009 he was awarded the $765,000 dollar Skoll Prize for Social Entrepreneurship by philanthropist [[Jeffrey Skoll|Jeff Skoll]].<ref name=Newswire>{{cite news|title=Canadian NGO Wins Prestigious Skoll Award and Endorsement from US Leadership in Afghanistan|url=http://www.newswire.ca/en/story/493815/canadian-ngo-wins-prestigious-skoll-award-and-endorsement-from-us-leadership-in-afghanistan|accessdate=26 October 2014|agency=Newswire|date=December 15, 2009}}</ref> The University of Alberta awarded him a Distinguished Alumnus Award in 2013.<ref name=Pilger /> He received a [[Queen Elizabeth II Diamond Jubilee Medal]] for professional excellence.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Cohen|first1=Andrew|title=Let's find a better way to honour Canadians|url=http://www.canada.com/story.html?id=4d434f3f-864b-4172-8636-c15158af46fc|accessdate=19 December 2014|agency=Times Colonist Victoria|date=Oct 31, 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150221151005/http://www.canada.com/story.html?id=4d434f3f-864b-4172-8636-c15158af46fc|archivedate=21 February 2015|df=}}</ref>
==Personal life== Gilmore is married to [[Catherine McKenna]], the Minister of Environment and Climate Change and the [[Liberal Party of Canada|Liberal]] MP for [[Ottawa Centre]].<ref name="Catherine McKenna">{{cite web | url=http://www.canada.com/story.html?id=e3d5dc04-83b2-4c25-add7-bbfe2a59eeeb | title=Small NGO, big results | publisher=[[Ottawa Citizen]] | date=7 January 2015 | accessdate=31 October 2015 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160324222748/http://www.canada.com/story.html?id=e3d5dc04-83b2-4c25-add7-bbfe2a59eeeb | archivedate=24 March 2016 | df= }}</ref>

{{one source|date=January 2012}} [[File:Bündner Schwabenkinder 1907.JPG|thumb|Swabian children from Graubünden at Arnach (1907)]]
The '''[[Swabia]]n children''' (German: ''Schwabenkinder'') were peasant children from poor families in the [[Alps]] of Austria and Switzerland who went to find work on farms in [[Upper Swabia]] and the [[Swabian Jura]]. Usually they were sent by their parents to become seasonal workers. They were taken in spring and brought to the child markets in Germany, mainly in [[Upper Swabia]], where they would be purchased or "rented" by farmers for the season. This use of children as workers was most widespread in the 19th century.
The march [[Principal passes of the Alps|over the Alps]] to Germany proved often difficult and exhausting. Usually their guide was a priest, who was also responsible for ensuring the children had a warm stable to sleep in.
The marches were large, organised groups of several thousand children, taken over the snow-covered mountains often still dressed in rags. It was not uncommon for five and six-year-old children to be taken.
The American press began a campaign in 1908 exposing the Swabian children, describing the child market in [[Friedrichshafen]] as a "barely concealed slave market".
The child markets were abolished in 1915, yet the trade of children did not end completely until compulsory schooling for foreign children was introduced in [[Württemberg]] in 1921.
Many immigration certificates from Swabia show surnames typical of [[county of Tyrol|Tyrol]] and other regions the children were taken from (e.g. ''Braxmeier'' from ''Braxmarer'').
==Film==
* ''Schwabenkinder'', TV film (first aired 2003), director: [[Jo Baier]], actors: [[Tobias Moretti]], [[Vadim Glowna]]
The movie is based on the novel "Die Schwabenkinder - Die Geschichte des Kaspanaze" (''"The Swabian Children - The Story of Kaspanaze"'') by [[Elmar Bereuter]] ({{ISBN|3-7766-2304-7}}).
'''Film synopsis:''' After his mother is killed in an avalanche, the farmer boy Kaspar is sent by his struggling father to work in Swabia. Together with other children from the village, their guide ([[Tobias Moretti]]) brings the group to the child market at [[Ravensburg]]. There the miraculous story begins: The brutal treatment of the boy by the farmer, his escape, emigration to the United States, and final home coming to his village many years later to visit his dying father.

{{Orphan|date=February 2009}} '''''The Hard Copy Observer''''' is a regular publication of [[Lyra Research]] based in [[Newtonville, Massachusetts]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Company Overview of Lyra Research, Inc.|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/snapshot.asp?privcapId=22563242|publisher=Bloomberg|accessdate=November 20, 2016}}</ref> It is a business (as opposed to consumer) publication targeted at the [[Printing]] and [[Document imaging|Imaging]] business, and is widely considered the premier authoritative factual source for that industry. [[Tekrati]], a firm in the [[Analyst relations|Analyst Relations]] business, summarizes The Hard Copy Observer as "a leading publication serving the industry and, in fact, the printer industry bible."<ref>[http://analystfirms.tekrati.com/detail.asp?id=88 ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061124134328/http://analystfirms.tekrati.com/detail.asp?id=88 |date=November 24, 2006 }}</ref>
==History and profile== Volume 1, Number 1 of "the Observer" was published in October 1991. Its founder as well as original editor and publisher is Charles LeCompte, who remains as publisher (2010). The success of the publication spawned what grew to be a much larger marketing research organization, Lyra Research, headquartered in [[Newton, Massachusetts]]. A companion monthly newsletter, ''The Hard Copy Supplies Journal'', was also developed to focus on the consumables portion of the business.
The first edition was 28 pages in length, and featured front-page stories about [[Xerox]], [[Apple Computer]], and [[Dataproducts]]. Its "look" was the no-nonsense black-and-white format that for the most part has remained unchanged. Today's subscription rate is $650 a year, compared to 1991's $495 a year, though the average edition's length, in its print form, grew to over 50 pages. Then as now, the publication is subscriber-supported with virtually no advertising.
The print version of the publication ended with the August 2009 issue,<ref>{{cite web|title=The Hard Copy Observer -- now online!|url=http://jimlyonsobservations.blogspot.com.tr/2009/09/hard-copy-observer-now-online.html|publisher=Jim Lyons Observations|accessdate=1 January 2016|date=23 September 2009}}</ref> and beginning in September 2009, the newsletter content was continuously updated and available via web access.
In April 2012, the Photizo Group acquired Lyra Research,<ref>{{cite news|title=Photizo Group Acquires Lyra Research|url=http://www.zdnet.com/article/photizo-group-acquires-lyra-research/|accessdate=1 January 2016|work=ZDNet|date=13 April 2012}}</ref> and the online ''Observer'' was phased out as it was merged with Photizo's industry news resources.

{{Infobox convention | name = '''Tiger Conference''' | image = [[File:Logo of the Tiger Conference.png|300px|]] | status = | genre = Business | frequency = Annual | location = [[Kiev]] | country = [[Ukraine]] | first = 2012 | last = | founders = [[Kyiv Post]] | CEO = | organizer = | attendance = | website = https://tiger.kyivpost.com/ }} '''Tiger Conference''' is an annual [[conference]], founded in 2012<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://labs.kyivpost.com/tiger2017/6th_TIGER_Conference.pdf|title=Tiger Conference Chronology|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|language=|accessdate=}}</ref> by the [[Kyiv Post]]. The conference brings together more than 400 [[Ukrainians|Ukrainian]] and world leaders, top managers, top executives of leading companies, media, parliamentarians, diplomats and opinion leaders to exchange ideas about the future of [[Ukraine]] in a changing world.
Since 2016, Kyiv Post has launched a "Top 30 Under 30" [[List of awards|award ceremony]], selected by jury on the basis of nominations from readers and business community. This ceremony completes the conference.
As of 2018, the Tiger Conference has become an independent discussion platform for discussing the strongest challenges of Ukraine.
== Format == The event holds 4 panel discussions, speeches delivered by key speakers, 2 sectional meetings and the award ceremony of the 30 most successful young Ukrainians "TOP30UNDER30".
== Top 30 Under 30 == [[File:Logo 30UNDER30 Ukraine.png|thumb|Official logo of the nomination]] The Top 30 Under 30 [[nomination]] is a popular practice among international editions, research organizations such as [[Forbes]]. In Ukraine, the award was launched in 2016 by [[Kyiv Post|KyivPost]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://tiger.kyivpost.com/page1414128.html|title=6th Tiger Conference|website=tiger.kyivpost.com|accessdate=2018-10-03}}</ref> in partnership with the [[Victor Pinchuk Foundation]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://pinchukfund.org/ua/news/17090/|title=Фонд Віктора Пінчука - Новини|website=pinchukfund.org|accessdate=2018-10-03}}</ref>
Every year special jury creates a list of the top 30 most successful young Ukrainians, who inspires and proves that Ukraine has a bright future.
The winners of the nomination must be a [[Citizenship|citizen]] of Ukraine who has not yet reached the age of 30 years and have outstanding achievements in the fields of [[education]], [[health care]], [[business]], [[science]], [[medicine]], social activities, [[art]] and other fields.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.prostir.ua/?grants=nominatsiya-top-30-under-30-vid-kyiv-post-tryvaje-pryjom-zayavok|title=Номінація TOP 30 UNDER 30 від Kyiv Post – триває прийом заявок {{!}} Громадський простір|website=www.prostir.ua|language=uk|accessdate=2018-10-03}}</ref> The award is realized in a crystal engraving [[Figurine|statuette]].
